name: Latham, Mark, MP
text:
—In question time today, we saw another embarrassing performance by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. She is embarrassing to the government, she is embarrassing to the parliament and she is embarrassing to the nation. She is a minister with defence responsibilities who can barely answer a question at the dispatch box. She can barely answer a question and can barely give any sort of credible defence of government policy, and now she is a minister who has fled from the chamber rather than face an important debate about border protection and national security. She is unfit for the job; she is incapable of defending this nation. Mrs Vale may well be a very nice lady—I am sure of that—but, quite frankly, I would not want her defending my street let alone defending our country. I would not want her involved in the protection of our borders or our national security. She is not up to the job. She may be another favourite of the Prime Minister but she is not a favourite of the Australian people, who are looking for a competent minister who is across the brief and able to defend our borders and secure our nation.
The truth is that Australia needs a coastguard. More than ever, we need a cop on the beat. We need an effective maritime policing capacity. In one respect, it is amazing that Australia does not already have a coastguard. We are the world's largest island—the world's only island continent—with 37,000 kilometres of coastline. We have all that coastline but no coastguard. It is a major deficiency in our border protection strategy and a major deficiency in the nation's security. It is even worse than that: not only do we not have a coastguard but our nearest neighbour to the north, Indonesia—the world's largest archipelago—does not have a coastguard either. It is no wonder that our part of the world is so vulnerable to the drug runners, the gun smugglers and the pirate fishermen; and we are vulnerable to people-smuggling over the medium term.
It also needs to be said that the coastguard is an effective part of a strategy against terrorism. There is no doubt that terrorists look to nations with porous borders. Terrorists are attracted to nations that do not guard their coasts; they are attracted to nations with porous borders. We need a coastguard on so many fronts. We need the cop on the beat to deter the gun runners, to deter the drug smugglers, to combat the pirate fishermen, to fight the terrorists and to deter the people smugglers over the medium to longer term. This is an important part of Australia's national security strategy. 
The truth is that the Howard government has gone soft on border protection because it has the wrong border protection strategy. You cannot be strong and effective on border protection unless you have the right strategy. The government has a strategy that, quite frankly, is uncoordinated and unsustainable. It is unsustainable on the basis of cost. The government's strategy is to have Navy frigates patrolling our Indian Ocean territories and waterways at a cost of $1 million a day. So it would take just two frigates operating for 300 days in a year to meet the full cost of Labor's comprehensive national coastguard network. The government's strategy is unsustainable. The government's strategy is ineffective. The government has gone soft on border protection because it has the wrong strategy. We need a coastguard to make up for the current arrangements, which are hopelessly inadequate. They are inadequate on the basis of cost. How can anyone defend a strategy that has Navy frigates acting as patrol boats at a cost of $1 million a day? It is cost ineffective. It is one of the most inefficient things you can do with our valuable Navy resources.
The Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence was in here today demeaning the Navy by saying it is little. In her world, it must be little and very expensive. She has the frigates out there at $1 million a day. It is also true to say that the current strategy is a poor use of operational resources. We have Navy personnel who have to jump 10 metres into the water to get asylum seekers out of the water. These boats have not been built for this purpose. Morale is falling. There is no doubt about that. The minister can deny it and talk about what is happening in the Gulf, but she should have a talk to the sailors who are out there on the frigates patrolling the Australian coast about the drop in morale. They have been trained for a war-fighting operation and not to act on border protection patrol boats. Morale is falling, and we are losing the skills of a war-fighting Navy. If you take our Navy and dedicate it to the wrong purpose—a purpose for which our sailors have never been trained—you will lose expertise, you will lose skills and you will lose morale. The minister can talk about an operation up in the Gulf, but the truth is that in our own backyard morale and skills are falling.
The other problem we have is that the Coastwatch arrangement is a dog's breakfast. It is totally uncoordinated and unfocused; it is an absolute dog's breakfast. The truth is that we can do much better, and that is the purpose of Labor's positive solution of establishing an Australian coastguard. Why do we need the coastguard? We need the coastguard because of the findings of the Australian Illicit Drug Report. They are that Customs seizures amount to just one per cent of the heroin required to satisfy the Australian market—that is, 99 per cent of heroin crosses our borders undetected. If you had a concern about safety on our streets or about heroin peddlers in our suburbs, you would have an Australian coastguard to defend our borders and to stop the rush of heroin into this country. We need a coastguard also because of the problem of illegal hand guns. It is estimated that there are 100,000 illegal hand guns circulating in Australia, and every one of them is imported illegally.
—The last time Australian Customs apprehended a gun runner crossing our coastline—and it was in the electorate of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who is making a bit of noise; he might remember the last time Australian Customs apprehended a drug runner crossing our coastline—was four years ago, in 1998, in the Kimberleys. So Customs have not been effective.
—That's right.
—He says, `That's right.' He is proud of the achievement of Customs in not having apprehended a gun runner since doing so up in the Kimberleys in 1998. That is another reason we need a coastguard. The government boasts of an agreement made last Friday at COAG to ban about 20 per cent of the hand guns in Australia. Bigger and better results would be achieved by establishing a coastguard. In the calender year 2001, Customs seized a grand total of 232 illegal hand guns. That is a bad performance. If it were not so serious, it would be a joke. They seized a grand total of 232 hand guns. Establishing an Australian coastguard could make our streets and suburbs safer, keep the guns off our streets and achieve a big result for community security. So too for the problem of pirate fishermen. If we want to do something about the pirate fishermen, we need effective border protection. We need a cop on the beat. We need an Australian coastguard. 
Of course, Labor have a solution. Unlike the government, we are not talking about these things; we are putting forward constructive policy solutions. There are four aspects to our national coastguard network. The first of those is the new hardware. Labor will commission three new purpose-built ships, built in Australia, generating Australian jobs and adding to our important shipbuilding industry. This fleet of three 80-metre ships, with helicopters, fills a critical capability gap. The truth is that, under the current flawed strategy, the Navy patrol boats are too small to protect our Indian Ocean territories, including Christmas Island, yet the Navy frigates are too expensive at $1 million a day to do the job efficiently. We need the coastguard fleet that a Crean Labor government will commission after the next election. The fleet will be headquartered at Darwin, with boats stationed at Cairns and Broome. There will be no impact on the defence budget; Navy resources will be unaffected. This is a win-win scenario: new hardware, a new coastguard fleet to undertake all these important border protection functions.
The second aspect of our coastguard network is the new personnel—250 new staff, as part of a coastguard staff entitlement of 2,000. The staff on the new boats are, of course, important, but the coastguard staff will also be posted on existing Navy and Customs patrol boats to perform surveillance and interdiction duties and also the vital maritime policing functions.
—To do the job properly.
—That is right: to do the job properly, as should have been happening for years. Our new coastguard personnel will be trained using state-of-the-art technology at the Australian Maritime College at Launceston in the electorate of Bass. The third aspect of our strategy is the coastguard volunteers. John Howard says that he wants Australians to be alert to the threat of terrorism. Labor says that Australians should be alert but they should also have the opportunity and capacity to join a voluntary organisation to help make Australia safer. As a nation, generally, we do not look after our volunteers well enough. Labor's coastguard volunteers will change this pattern of neglect. We need a huge national effort to patrol and protect our borders. Labor will bring together the two existing organisations, the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol and the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard Association, to form a new coastguard volunteer network, a vast network of commercial and recreational vessels forming perhaps Australia's largest voluntary effort in the security and defence of our nation.
And the potential is there. This is the potential the Howard government has totally neglected. It has given no recognition or encouragement to the coastguard volunteers. In Australia, we have 12,000 commercial vessels. We have 500,000 registered recreational boats. They should be the eyes and ears of a nation concerned about terrorism, the eyes and ears of a nation concerned about border protection and the eyes and ears of the world's largest island continent, with 37,000 kilometres of coast. They should offer the surveillance, the training and all the services that are needed to make our nation safe. Labor's policy will provide training and badging for the coastguard vessels and the volunteers, plus financial incentives—discounts on boat registration for all of the volunteers and also communication support in areas that are targeted by our coastguard strategy. The provision of $125 million is an investment in our volunteers over four years. It is the recognition and encouragement at long last that they truly deserve. 
The fourth and final aspect of our national coastguard network is the new intelligence capacity. Good intelligence is the key driver of effective border protection. Currently, the Coastwatch effort is unable to direct the surveillance effort. It is contracted in by other agencies, so it cannot actually control the surveillance strategy. Labor's policy brings the coordination together and also provides an additional $30 million investment in fixed seabed array technology—that is, a seabed sonar system to increase the reach of our surveillance and national intelligence effort.
So this is a comprehensive national network of coastguard services—the new ships, the new personnel, the thousands of volunteers and the new intelligence capacity—all provided in a cost-effective way and far more effective than anything that has been achieved by the Howard government. We need to secure our nation, and it is not only Labor saying these things. Our policy has been endorsed by the people who know. The Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol has said that it `welcomes the proposal of a single federal agency that would coordinate the safety and protection of our coastline'. It went on to say:
The concept of a national coast guard manned by well trained professionals and supported by equally well trained volunteers works very well in many countries overseas, most notable the United States of America.
And then there is the Australia Defence Association. What did they have to say about our coastguard policy? They said:
The government has again over-reacted to the Opposition's policy with an inflammatory and generally superficial response that simply reflects the bureaucratic interest groups. They would do better to hijack—
and adopt—
Labor's proposal.
Here is the Prime Minister talking about interest groups, but the truth is that when it comes to interest groups he is paralysed by the bureaucracy, paralysed by the sectional interest groups and unable to give this nation the border protection, the coastguard services that it truly needs. We have the support of the Australia Defence Association. It is a great shame that the assistant Minister for Defence is not even in the chamber to hear these ringing endorsements of Labor's coastguard policy. She is too scared to give an answer, she is too scared to engage in a debate, she truly has lost the plot and she gives the Australian people no confidence or security that she is up to the important task of acting as one of our defence ministers at this critical time in Australia's history. And what does Hugh White, one the pre-eminent defence and intelligence experts in Australia, have to say about the coastguard issue? He says:
If we want more patrol boats—
for border protection—
... almost anyone could operate them more cheaply than the Navy.
That is another ringing endorsement of Labor's cost-effective, efficient strategy. We can do a lot better than Minister Danna Vale, we can do a lot better than a government that is paralysed by bureaucratic interests and sectional considerations, a government that has ignored the potential need for an Australian coastguard. It is one thing to have a minister who is regarded as a nice person, but niceness is not going to help Australia in the war against terror. Niceness is not going to help Australians to feel more secure, it is not going to get the drugs off our streets and it is not going to get the illegal guns out of our communities. Having a nice minister—a little favourite that the Prime Minister can pat on the head; the new Jackie Kelly of the Australian parliament—is hopelessly inadequate for the Australian people at this critical time. We need good policy. The world's largest island continent with the world's largest coastline needs a coastguard. That is the bottom line: we need a coastguard. The government should be sensible enough to put the public interest first and adopt our policy right now.

name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
text:
—Character assassination is no substitute for policy. The proposition from the member for Werriwa is a complete throwback to propositions that have already been rejected by the Australian people. I believe the proposition before the House today is a sign to the people of Australia that the Australian Labor Party are still ignoring them. Over 12 months ago, the people of Australia had a number of things to contend with in the 2001 federal election and one of them was Labor's proposition for a coastguard. It was roundly defeated. The Australian Labor Party need to understand that that defeat, that rejection of that policy, means that they should move on, cut their losses and look for something else. But, no, the Australian Labor Party are still ignoring the people of Australia. The proposition underscores the Australian Labor Party's complete desperation. The proposition also signals to smugglers that Australia would be back in business as far as they are concerned if the Australian Labor Party were ever to form government again. The people smugglers and drug smugglers would enjoy the day that the Australian Labor Party were re-elected to government. 
This proposition from the member for Werriwa also ignores the public debate that has occurred since the last election, which continues to roundly reject this proposition for a coastguard. The proposition also weakens the standing of the Royal Australian Navy, an organisation whose men and women are charged with the important task of protecting the seas around this nation. This proposition, as the Minister for Veterans Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence rightly said during question time, also says that we will substitute three small patrol boats for the 15 boats which are currently employed in the tasks that the member for Werriwa says are not being done properly. This is not about coastguard; this is about leader guard—although, if I were the member for Hotham, I would be greatly concerned if the member for Werriwa mounted a defence of my leadership. People in my own electorate are wondering why the Australian Labor Party continue to ignore, after being told time and time again, the fact that this proposition for a coastguard simply does not stack up; that it will take away important resources from the Royal Australian Navy and it will take away the important task that the Royal Australian Navy performs. People cannot understand why the Labor Party do not get on with the business of backing the government's efforts with regard to border protection.
The opposition's continual insistence on bringing back a coastguard policy for border control is simply recycling ideas that have been rejected. They still do not understand that effective border protection strategies are already in place at this time. The rest of Australia has moved on, but the Labor Party continue to hold on to what was in their minds prior to the last election. They do not realise that they lost and that they need to move on in every possible way, including policy development. It is almost one year since we were promised a 1,000-day-long reform—a reform which would have matured after the next election is due. People in Australia will have to wait for two elections before they see a reformed Labor Party. At the end of the day, Labor still have a long way to go in developing workable policies to deal with unauthorised arrivals. The market has made its choice, but the Labor Party ignore what the market has had to say. In contrast with these untested policy experiments that are proposed by Labor, the Howard government's strategies are working. We have in place a comprehensive, coordinated strategy dealing with border protection, yet the opposition want to impose another layer of bureaucracy—something else to trip up everybody on the high seas. They want to change boats midstream. The proof that the Howard government's strategies are working is that there have been no boat arrivals on the Australian mainland since August 2001 and no boat arrivals in any Australian territory since 9 December 2001, which sounds awfully like a year ago yesterday. The Howard government have a system which is comprehensive and is working.
The mantra of `coastguard' is something that the Labor Party seem to shout every time they need a lifeline or a circuit-breaker in contemporary political debate. They feel themselves to be sinking into irrelevance in public debate. The Labor Party are divided on all these issues. The member for Fremantle has made well known her position on Labor Party policy and policy development on the front bench. She cannot even guarantee that she will contest the next election as a Labor candidate unless other policy changes are made at the ALP conference next year. The member for Werriwa is trying very hard to defend the constant exposure that his leader has had on this particular issue. His leader is being buffeted by waves of discontent within his party, muttering about what the Labor Party stands for. The `Friends of the ABC' faction is alive and well—that is, the `Anyone but Crean' faction. In raising this proposition today, the member for Werriwa is quite deliberately weakening his leader. 
The effort to combat the people-smuggling trade is ongoing. It draws on the combined resources of a number of different agencies, including my department—the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs—the law enforcement community, the intelligence community and the defence community. The government's approach comprises three main elements. It is worth repeating them for the public record. The first is the prevention of the problem by minimising the outflows from countries of origin and the secondary outflows from countries of first asylum. The second is working with other countries to disrupt people smugglers and to intercept their clients en route to their intended destination, while also ensuring that people in need of refugee protection are identified and assisted as early as possible. The third is the development of appropriate reception arrangements for unauthorised arrivals who reach Australia, focusing on the early assessment of the refugee status of each person and the prompt removal of those who are not refugees or who are refugees but who cannot access effective protection elsewhere. This is working. This program, this coordinated effort by the government, is working in the area of border protection and does not need the sort of interruption to the process that the Labor Party is proposing. It does not need the sort of signal that is being sent to people smugglers and smugglers of other items which come to Australia—that is, that if the Labor Party were elected again to the government benches, they would be back in business and big time.
In September last year, the Howard government introduced significant legislative changes to border control and the management of unauthorised boat arrivals. I need to revisit all that happened in the lead-up to the last election, because it seems to have escaped those opposite. The government has also enacted legislation to limit grounds for the judicial review of visa related matters in Australian courts. This measure addresses the problem of unsuccessful asylum seekers who are using court processes as a means to deter their removal.
Customs officers already have the powers that they need to do the job. They can board ships, question, arrest and carry firearms. They can pursue and stop ships on the open seas and they can seize vessels. Customs officers and the Australian Customs Service are well aware of the range of measures they have at their disposal and are well aware of their own efforts and the success of their efforts. Labor are completely ignoring these efforts and the experience of officers on the ground today doing that important job and gaining real yards in the area of border protection. This is another uncosted policy. The Australian Labor Party in opposition will, of course, continue to promise a range of measures that, at the end of the day, they know they will never have to implement—measures that would be financially irresponsible if for some reason they were ever re-elected to the treasury bench. 
This coastguard would be more costly. It is an irresponsible, wasteful and reckless proposal. It would create a new bureaucracy with all the overhead costs that that entails. The proposal to transfer patrol boats from Defence and vessels from Customs is short-sighted and dangerous to national security. Defence needs to retain all of its patrol boats, which are critical for its training and development regime. Even more stupidly, under the Australian Labor Party proposal Defence and Customs would in fact need to purchase new vessels to pick up on the non-Coastwatch work that their vessels would be doing. This is a stupid and reckless proposal and it concerns me that after all of the years of debate on this matter, after all of the opportunities the people of Australia have had to judge this and after the views of so many other people involved in the Australian community who comment on these sorts of matters on a daily basis, the Australian Labor Party still do not get it. They still do not get the fact that, after September last year, when the debate in Australia homed in particularly on these issues, the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Brand, put up a proposition for a coastguard as an alternative measure for border protection to deal with the government's already effective strategy, which was introduced as a result of all of the things that were happening to Australia and which was endorsed by the people of Australia. It is interesting that the member for Hotham, the member for Werriwa and several others—and there were only a few, and in fact it was interesting to watch so many members opposite leave when the member for Werriwa started speaking and to note that there is not a universal view on the other side—are still keeping alive this ridiculous proposition. 
It is interesting to note that Mike Carlton on Sydney radio 2UE on 27 November interviewed the Leader of the Opposition. I will quote some of the highlights from that particular interview, where Carlton understood very well the absolute lack of support in the Australian community for this. The transcript is as follows: 
CREAN: I'm talking about the Indian Ocean, the blue water activity—
he was talking about patrol boats and the potential for a coastguard. It continues:
CARLTON: We have patrol boats in the Indian Ocean. Where'd you get that idea?
CREAN: Um, these—what they do is to send the frigates out into the deep water operations and they cost a million dollars a day, Mike. A million a day.
CARLTON: We have ... patrol boats all over our Coastguard. I don't know where you got this idea that they can't operate in deep water? That's just nuts.
It goes on:
CARLTON: Would you ... go down to the Southern Ocean in an 80-metre vessel in the height of winter?
CREAN: All the advice that we've had is that they can.
I tell you what: they would want to have a good union because it is going to be pretty cold down there in the Southern Ocean in the middle of winter. This is the sort of nonsense proposal the Australian Labor Party are endorsing in this proposition today. It continues:
CARLTON: Hmm. I can't see it working, I've got to tell you but I admire you, at least you've got a policy on something—
so Carlton recognises that the Australian Labor Party do not have many policies, but at least they have a policy on something—
but it just seems to be utterly wasteful duplication of the maritime and military skills we have.
If Mike Carlton could give better advice, I am waiting to hear it. He gave great advice to the Leader of the Opposition last week and Simon Crean still does not get it. After the interview, Carlton summed it all up. He said:
Thanks a lot. Simon Crean, the Leader of the Opposition. Well look, it's a nice feel-good idea, a Coastguard to patrol our seas and oceans, cop on the beat—he obviously likes that phrase—but it's half-cocked, half-baked.
Opposition members interjecting—
—They are all saying, `Hear, hear!' Carlton continued:
Where do you get the crews? They don't come overnight. The Navy is at full stretch recruiting and keeping its own people. To use the Navy phrase you have to raise 'em, train 'em and sustain 'em—that doesn't happen overnight. It's— you know. The patrol boats themselves, 80 metres—yes, good-sized ships, twice the size of the patrol boats we've got—but Simon Crean thinks our existing patrol boats can't go into blue waters, that's rubbish. Absolute rubbish. They're there all the time, that's all they do. Whether these 80-metre Coastguard vessels he's talking about could handle the Southern Ocean in winter, I doubt very much. It's tough enough for the bigger frigates to do that. Well, what sort of armament would they have? A gun up the front, he said. Well he didn't know much about that, either.
The proposition put by Mike Carlton really says it all. Just last week the Leader of the Opposition was given absolute sound advice by a well-established, highly credentialled and highly experienced media commentator. Mike Carlton is someone with experience in other parts of the world as well as here in Australia, someone who calls a spade a spade, and without any doubt he said that Emperor Crean was completely naked on the question of a coastguard.  
Yet today we have the member for Werriwa coming in here in support of his leader—I do not think so. At the end of the day, this proposition has been put forward by the member for Werriwa to add further embarrassment to the member for Hotham. This is all about the Australian Labor Party, without any doubt and in a blatant way, promising everything that sounds good. This is `a feel-good proposition', as Mike Carlton said last week—a nice sounding, feel-good proposition. But Labor are showing the people of Australia, the Navy, the people involved in the Customs Service, the people involved in the everyday hard work of proving the great result that we have had over the past 12 months—and they are also showing the people-smugglers—that if they were elected back to the treasury bench there would be confusion, not coordination, and bureaucracy aplenty but not any depth to the services provided. Their policy is soft on sovereignty, on border control and on costing. The Labor Party proposition is also showing that they are somewhat soft in the head because, after some 15 or 16 months of public debate on the proposition of a coastguard, the Australian Labor Party still have not got the message. This proposition today, initiated by the member for Werriwa, is rejected outright by the government because it does not work. The Australian Labor Party need to wake up to the fact that that is the case. I look forward to them spending the Christmas period properly understanding the reality that they should be confronting, and that is that they have lost three elections on the run, and the people of Australia have spoken. (Time expired)

name: Zahra, Christian, MP
text:
—I think we have heard just about everything in this place now. We have had the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs stand up here and talk about defence matters and matters to do with national security. It is like a scene from a movie. We looked for the Minister for Defence and we looked for the assistant minister for defence, but who did we get? We got the minister for citizenship. We may as well have got the minister for child care or the minister for anything else. We wanted a serious debate with the government in relation to this policy. The minister got up here and quoted Mike Carlton. Who is Mike Carlton? Is he an expert on defence matters? Is he an expert on national security? Is he an ex military officer? Is he anyone who has any experience in dealing with matters to do with national security? The answer to those questions is no.
The member for Werriwa, who has responsibility for this in the shadow ministry, quoted the Australia Defence Association, who have endorsed Labor's policy. He quoted the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, who have supported Labor's policy. He quoted the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, who have also endorsed Labor's policy. The minister for citizenship came in here, quoted Mike Carlton, and said that Mike Carlton is against Labor's policy and therefore it is not a good thing. I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, that on our side—on the side of this good, decent public policy—we have all the people who know what they are talking about. On the government side we have a minister who does not have portfolio responsibility for this area. He came in here and read a speech from a couple of years ago that he pulled out of a dusty old drawer in his office, and he read it off without any proper analysis of what Labor's policy has to offer.
—And then he scampers off!
—I have just been advised that he is scampering off. I wish he would stay because he might learn a thing or two. In public life the test of how serious you are about something is the resources you are prepared to commit to it. Under our policy—our fully costed policy—we have allocated $612½ million over four years to underscore Labor's commitment to border protection. It is all well and good for people in public life to stand up and say, `I'm for education', `I'm for defence' or `I'm for health', but the real test is how much you are prepared to put behind that commitment. The Labor Party have put more than $600 million behind our commitment. We are serious about this policy, we are serious about border protection and we are serious about it for a lot of good reasons. 
When you talk about maritime policing, you are talking about things that affect people's lives. You are talking about people smugglers, gun runners, drug smugglers and illegal fishing, and you are also talking about terrorists. These things are all very real risks to Australians. These are things that affect people's lives, and that is why we are concerned about them. That is why we have put in place this comprehensive policy to deal seriously with this important security matter. The one thing to never lose sight of when you talk about border protection is that it is not about false nationalism, it is not about jingoism and it is not about some of the stuff the hooray henrys on the other side go on about. It is about people's lives. On this side we are concerned about the impact of illegal importation of hand guns, illegal fishing, people smugglers and other illegal activity that takes place right now without any fear on the part of those responsible that they will be caught and brought to account for their actions. Right now maritime policing is a very vague concept. Who is involved, who is responsible and who has enforcement powers are very grey areas. We are about tightening that up and giving people real authority and the real resources they need to tackle this important issue.
The member for Werriwa—the shadow minister for community security, who has carriage of this for us—made a few important remarks in relation to the appropriateness of the resources the government are putting towards this task. We are about making sure that the government resources put towards border protection meet the task. Right now inappropriate government resources are being put towards this task, and it is just not working. It is not just the Labor Party who says it is not working: people in the defence community, people involved in national security and people involved in the Volunteer Coast Guard all accept that the current arrangements are not sustainable. They are not working effectively and they come at an extremely high cost to government. The reason is simple: they are using the wrong gear for the job. It is as simple as that. This has a substantial impact on the personnel involved. These people signed up to the Royal Australian Navy with the understanding that the Royal Australian Navy was used for war fighting in Australia and had a primary defence role. That is what those brave sailors understood when they signed up to be part of the Royal Australian Navy. Now they are performing a range of tasks which have nothing to do with what they have been trained to do or the functions they have set out to discharge.
We are about letting the Royal Australian Navy get on with the business of defence and putting in place a proper Australian coastguard to deal with issues of maritime policing. We understand that when you have a problem you need to think seriously about the resources you need to bring to dealing with that problem. The government seems absolutely incapable of understanding that when you talk about border protection you are not talking about defence. When you speak to people involved in this area, one thing comes through loud and clear: people are not happy about the existing arrangements, in which the Royal Australian Navy is used for this function. We are serious about letting the Royal Australian Navy get on with defence because we think the defence of Australia is an important priority and should not be diminished in any way by involving the Royal Australian Navy in other matters. What could be more important than defence? What could be more important than letting those sailors and that expert staff deal with matters to do with the defence of our country? We say: let those people do that work, and put in place a professional maritime police force to act as an Australian coastguard to make sure that matters to do with border protection are taken seriously and dealt with effectively.
I want to address the volunteer component in the time I have left in this debate. This is about saying to citizens in Australia that we understand they are serious about border protection and that we are too. We are going to make it possible for those citizens who are concerned about border protection to play an active role in enforcing border protection in our country. This is not a policy which has been arrived at without talking to people. The Labor Party has spoken to the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard, the government agencies involved and other groups which are involved in the volunteer coastguard community. What people have said to us very clearly—and it was mentioned in the endorsements which were read out by the member for Werriwa—is that they all support the idea of having a properly resourced Australian coastguard. Everyone else, except for the government, can see that if you have 37,000 kilometres of coastline you need a coastguard. It comes as no surprise to anyone that with 37,000 kilometres of coastline we are detecting only about one per cent of the illegal drugs that come into this country. That affects our communities, the places where we live. This is why so many people in Australia will be keen to participate in a volunteer border protection effort. 
We are serious about those people who want to volunteer to be a part of the border protection effort. To underscore how seriously we take their volunteerism, we are going to resource it. There are a few important things which make up that support. We are going to sit down with the people who are involved in those volunteer coastguard agencies—the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol and the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard—and we are going to ask them to develop the charter for the new coastguard volunteer organisation. We are going to ask people who are involved in recreational fishing and tourism around the coastline, and also commercial fishermen, to participate in the coastguard volunteer patrol movement. We are going to ask those people to give us the intelligence which they have in relation to finding out where the ships are and where there is illegal activity. We are going to make it possible for those people to contribute to the volunteer effort and the professional effort involved in making sure that we have effective border protection in our country.
We are going to make sure that those people do that not just based on our saying: `You do this and that's all well and good, but we're not going to resource it properly.' What we are going to do is give those people a financial incentive as well for participating in our program. That is going to be contributed to them through discounted boat registration and also through assisting those people with new types of communications technology which will make their task easier. We are serious about border protection on this side of the House. We stand with the Australian Defence Association, the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard and every other thinking person in Australia who understands that with 37,000 kilometres of coastline Australia needs an Australian coastguard. (Time expired)

name: Gallus, Christine, MP
text:
—What do we have this time from the member for Werriwa? The hoary chestnut that is the coastguard. Let me see, how long has the idea of the coastguard been around? Way before your time, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, and way before my time. For 50 years the idea of a coastguard has come and gone. It has gone for a very good reason: it does not actually hold water. The idea itself sinks. It was raised originally in the 1950s, believe it or not. A Liberal government in the 1950s said, `Maybe we should have a look at a coastguard.' They had a look at the coastguard and they said at the end of it, `We don't need it.' We did not need it in the 1950s and we do not need it now. What Labor need, of course, is a policy. Desperate for a policy—any policy—they trawled through all the old ideas they could find and then, with sudden inspiration, the member for Werriwa looked around and said, `I've got one: it's a coastguard. Boy, we have got it. Let's show the Australian public that we are as good as anybody else and we can come up with a coastguard.'
Unfortunately, there are more than a few problems with the idea. First of all, to exclude the way that it was brought up as an old idea, what about duplication? This is what all the experts who have looked at it have said: `We have a Navy and we have Coastwatch. We do not need duplication of services. We do not need duplication of personnel, we do not need duplication of administration and we do not need to wear the extra cost to achieve nothing more.' What we have now is an extremely good set-up. For the benefit of the member for Werriwa and for Junior here, whose seat I do not remember, we will go through what we— 
—He didn't call you `Senior', did he.
—I would be glad to be called `Senior'.
 (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The parliamentary secretary will refer to members by their titles.
—Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, you could refresh my memory as to the title of the young man at the table.
—He is the honourable member for McMillan.
—For the information of the member for McMillan, we have a Customs—
—You don't hear me calling you an old woman.
—I have no objection if you want to call me an old woman.
—Order! The parliamentary secretary will ignore the interjections and the honourable member for McMillan will cease interjecting.
—I am very happy to go with the title of `old woman' if that is what you wish to call me. That is about the level of sophistication of the opposition, to refer to people as `old women'. I can wear that if that is what you want to call me. For your information, member for McMillan, we have a Customs National Marine Unit which operates a fleet of eight 35-metre Bay class vessels, capable of providing up to 2,400 sea days per year. In 2001-02, officers boarded more than 240 vessels. Customs Coastwatch has a fleet of 15 aircraft and two helicopters. It operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Coastwatch currently has access to the intelligence of the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Defence Force, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Both the National Marine Unit and Customs Coastwatch work with our Navy, Air Force and Army on two programs. Are you listening, member for McMillan? You might actually learn something here. Those two programs are Operation Relex, a program to detect, intercept and deter vessels carrying unauthorised arrivals, and Operation Cranberry, a program of air, sea and land surveillance to detect illegal activities such as smuggling and fishing.
—This is supposed to be a debating chamber, not a reading class.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, can I comment that, while the member for McMillan was making his speech, I did not make one interjection.
—Everyone else did.
—I believe I made one short interjection during the member for Werriwa's speech. Mr Deputy Speaker, could I ask that you enforce the same courtesy from the opposition as we gave to them. It would really assist. Let us have a look at this idea that the member for Werriwa has come up with. Do you know what it reminded me of? Tommy the tugboat! Instead of Tommy the tugboat, what have we got? We have Collie the coastguard, with its flotilla of little volunteer rowboats, rowing around the Pacific, rowing around the Indian Ocean, saying, `Oh, what can we see out here from our little fishing boats?' This is your idea of Australian security. This is your idea, instead of using the sophisticated system we already have—the Navy, Coastwatch and all that goes with it, and the Customs services and all the vessels. It is your idea to add this third ridiculous service, which is Collie the coastguard and its flotilla of little volunteers. Is that really what you think Australia's defence needs? Can I also remind the member for Werriwa, if you are talking about Australia, Australia's—
—You really should dry out, Chris.
—Could I ask the Deputy Speaker what the member for Werriwa meant when he said I should dry out?
—Order! It would assist the chair if the honourable member for Werriwa would withdraw that remark.
—The member for Hindmarsh is slurring her words, but I am happy to withdraw it. 
—The honourable member should withdraw without any additions.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you to the member for Werriwa for his gracious withdrawal. It is extremely gracious of you after suggesting that I was standing at the dispatch box, having drunk too much. It was a delightful withdrawal from the member for Werriwa. Can I go back to the whole question of this MPI today, which is the need for an effective border security strategy. Let us have a look at what happened between 1989 and 2001. There were 13,400 people who arrived in Australia between 1989 and 2001. In 2000-01, there were 4,137 boat arrivals. But, under coalition policy, there have been no boat arrivals on the Australian mainland since September 2001.

—This is the coalition's policy, and it works. This is the Pacific strategy. This is the strategy that this rabble of an opposition wants to get rid of. This is the strategy that works, and what does the opposition say? `Let's get rid of the Pacific strategy. Instead, we'll bring in Collie the coastguard and the flotilla of little volunteer boats.'

—Throwing out the Pacific strategy, what will we have instead? We will encourage the boat people, the people smugglers to bring people into Australia—
—You'll have to correct this Hansard.

—An absolute disgrace!
—Yes.
—At least we're sober.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the member for Werriwa said, `At least we're sober,' implying, I think, that I am not sober. Could I ask him to withdraw?
—Order! The honourable member for Werriwa will withdraw—formally, please.
—I'm not far wrong, but I withdraw.
—Order! I have warned the honourable member not to have additions.
—I withdraw.
—Can I say, seriously, that I take increasing offence to that. The implication there is typical of the nasty, mean-minded mouth that is the opposition in this place. It is a rabble that cannot come up with a policy; a rabble that cannot come up with an idea; a rabble that, to come up with a policy, has to go back to a 1950s idea from the Liberal government—indeed, a hopeless opposition. name: Gallus, Christine, MP
text:
—I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
The Telecommunications Competition Bill 2002 was passed by the Senate yesterday with a number of amendments made by the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats. The government is of the view that this piece of legislation should not be held up, as this would increase regulatory uncertainty for the telecommunications industry. Accordingly, the government believes the House should accept the amended bill. The government amendments aim to improve the proposed accounting separation framework which will be imposed upon Telstra. Firstly, Senate amendment (28) requires that all reasonable steps be taken to ensure that a special Telstra direction is given within six months of the commencement of the bill. The special Telstra direction is one that relates to Telstra's wholesale and retail operations. It requires the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, to exercise its powers to make rules requiring Telstra to keep and retain particular records, prepare reports based on those records and deliver those reports to the ACCC.
Secondly, amendment (28)(3) sets out the procedure that must be followed before the minister can make a special Telstra direction. The minister must publish a draft of that direction, invite people to make submissions on the draft direction within a specified time limit and consider any submissions that are received before making the direction. Thirdly, there are some minor technical amendments consequential to these amendments: Senate amendments (25) and (27). Fourthly, Senate amendment (26) clarifies that the minister may only give a direction to the ACCC to exercise its powers under this part in a way that means that the minister would not be able to give direction to the ACCC not to exercise its powers under these sections. Fifthly, Senate amendment (26)(1B) enables the minister to give a written direction to the ACCC requiring it to prepare a specified kind of analysis of the report and to publish the analysis within a specified period after receiving the report. Senate amendment (8) enables matters in an instrument to be incorporated by reference. 
The government amendments—Senate amendments (1) to (5)—also refine the amendments to the preselection provisions in the Telecommunications Act so that the ACCC will make the threshold decision on which services should be preselectable, but the ACA will determine the preselection requirement for those services, including exemptions from the requirements. Senate amendment (9) provides a right to seek merits review by the Australian Competition Tribunal in relation to access disputes that were notified to the ACCC before the introduction of the bill in the House of Representatives on 26 September 2002.
The government amendments also include some minor technical amendments. Senate amendment (18) ensures that provisions relating to the expiry time of anticipatory class exemptions and individual anticipatory exemptions are similar. Senate amendments (21) and (24) amend provisions relating to special access undertakings 152CBA and 152CBF to make it clear that the reference to active declared service is a declaration in the ordinary sense, under 152AL(3), not the deemed declaration that results from the proposals in the bill, under 152AL(7). Senate amendment (20) is an amendment to proposed subsection 152AL(7) to clarify that, if a special access undertaking is subject to limitations, the service specified in the undertaking is deemed to be a declared service and is therefore subject to the standard access obligations only to the extent that the service falls within the scope of the limitations.
In addition to the government amendments, some non-government amendments were passed by the Senate. While the government does not believe that these amendments are necessary, it does not consider that they detract from the significant overall benefits that will be achieved from the passage of the bill. Therefore, the government believes that the House should accept these amendments. These amendments include an amendment which means that telecommunications carriers will continue to have an obligation to lodge industry development plans. As a consequence of this amendment, a further government amendment was made to the bill to improve the exemption and verification process for industry development plans. This amendment allows the industry regulator, the Australian Communications Authority, to exempt certain specified kinds of carriers from the obligation to lodge industry development plans. Senate amendments (10) to (14) to part 3 of schedule 2 require the ACCC to hold a public inquiry before a declaration under section 152AL of the Trade Practices Act expires. Amendments to parts 11 and 12 of schedule 2—amendments (15) to (17), (19), (22) and (23)—remove the requirement that the ACCC have regard to the views of the minister in its consideration of anticipatory exemptions and special access undertakings.
The government considers that the bill as amended will provide a boost to competition by making the telecommunications competition regime more timely, effective and accountable. I therefore recommend that the House agree to the bill as amended.
Question agreed to.

name: McMullan, Bob, MP
text:
—I will be brief because the opposition support these amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Structured Settlements) Bill 2002. We supported them in the Senate, and they accord with our commitment to ensuring appropriate flexibility for structured settlements arrangements. We believe that offering this increased flexibility will mean that more people will take up such arrangements. This will provide consequent benefits both for the injured person, who will have a guarantee of a steady stream of income, and for insurers. It will allow continuing downward pressure to be placed on insurance premiums.
Consistent with our amendment to the same purpose, the opposition believe that the injured person should also be given the opportunity to purchase the annuities—that is, it should not be restricted just to the defendant insurer. It is a pity that the government has not picked up our amendment to that effect, but its amendment is in the same direction, although it does not achieve the purpose for which ours was designed. However, we supported the principle of the amendments in the Senate, and we are happy to support that again.
Question agreed to.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I move:
That amendments (9) and (13) be disagreed to.
These amendments are quite different and they apply to different sections of the bill but, for reasons of convenience, as discussed with the shadow minister, it is appropriate, given the time constraints, to handle them together. The government opposes amendment (9), which was moved by the opposition. It would allow the injured person or his or her legal representative to purchase a tax-free annuity or deferred lump sum. This replaces the requirement in the bill that the defendant or his or her insurer must agree to purchase the annuity. The government believes that requiring a defendant or his or her insurer to purchase an annuity in order to qualify for the tax concessions contained in this bill is desirable for a number of reasons. The tax exemption provided by this bill is intended to encourage the take-up of income streams in place of lump sum compensation. This has the potential to place downward pressure on settlement costs and therefore on insurance premiums. This benefit could be lost if the injured person could choose whether or not he or she purchased the annuity with what was essentially a lump sum compensation award. 
The approach of the government ensures that the annuity is used to meet expenses arising from injuries rather than for a different purpose. Further, under the amendment moved by the opposition, there would need to be administrative arrangements established to ensure that annuities are purchased with the funds received. The opposition amendment introduces the potential for an injured person to agree to purchase an annuity but not to follow through, despite his or her initial intentions. Requiring the defendant or insurer to make the final purchase ensures that only funds received in compensation are used to purchase the structured settlement, rather than other funds. Requiring the defendant or insurer to make the purchase also encourages financial planning beforehand. It enables settlements to be reached with the defendant to take into account longer term considerations.
Requiring defendants to purchase annuities has worked well overseas and is considered best practice. The requirement is supported by the structured settlements group, which represents both defendant and plaintiff based organisations. For these reasons, the government does not support the opposition amendment. In the circumstances, my friend opposite might be prepared to reconsider the position of the opposition.
Amendment (13) was moved by the Australian Democrats in the Senate. It will not come as any surprise to the House that the government also opposes the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. This amendment would require insured persons to obtain independent financial advice before entering into a structured settlement. However, there is no definition of an independent financial adviser in this context, so the provision would be difficult to enforce. The nature of the advice to be sought is also poorly defined. As it stands, each case would require a decision about whether the advice was independent and whether it was financial advice before adherence to the terms of the law could be determined. Furthermore, it is not clear what the consequences would be if the injured person failed to obtain independent financial advice. Because of the position of the amendment in the bill, it is not clear whether the intention is that this should mean that the exemption is denied. For these reasons, the government does not support the amendments circulated by the Democrats and carried in the other place.

name: McMullan, Bob, MP
text:
—Both of these amendments are suffering from what is called the `not invented here' syndrome—that is, if the government decides it cannot agree to amendments because they were not its idea, it comes up with the most convoluted arguments as to why it should not be the case. I accept that there are people who have been seriously involved in the longstanding and quite correct campaign in support of structured settlements who disagree with Labor's amendment in principle. I do not agree with them, but I do accept that. However, I have to say that, although Labor were not passionate about the Democrats amendment—we supported it in principle, but it was not ours—the government was really straining to come up with an argument that warranted voting against it.
I want to say something in support of both amendments, particularly that which we initiated, but I want to make it clear right at the beginning that we have said from the outset that our commitment has been, since long before the last election and long before the crisis became publicly perceived in the areas of medical indemnity insurance, public liability and related matters, that we wanted to see structured settlements in place. It was our policy at the last election, and we will do nothing to interfere with it. So we will not be pursuing these amendments in the Senate in any way which runs the risk of holding up the bill. We want the bill to pass. It is a great pity it will not be a slightly better bill; nevertheless, structured settlements is a very positive principle and we welcome the government belatedly on board for the proposition. When we proposed it in the lead-up to the last election, they thought it was a bad idea and proposed not to do any such thing. It is another case of `not invented here'. I sometimes feel slightly guilty: if we had not proposed it, the government might have done it a lot earlier. If we had not proposed the amendment, the government might have considered the proposition more favourably—but there is this `not invented here' syndrome that gets in the way of good policy from time to time. 
With regard to our amendment—and I will be brief because it has been debated both here and in the Senate—I think the government has the economics of this wrong. The proposal that the opposition put forward would have enabled an injured person or their legal representative to buy a tax concessional annuity as part of a settlement. Essentially what we are talking about is equality of rights to put offers on the table at the time of the negotiations. One of the primary roles of government in a market economy is to make sure that people who get involved in negotiations have some sort of equal bargaining power. This proposition would have allowed it; the government's proposition does not. Our proposal would have ensured that the uptake of structured settlements was encouraged on its own merits rather than because of any inherent and structured unfairness in the bargaining process.
We have taken on board representations that people have made to us about how it would be simpler to remove the timing concerns from the debate by restricting the purchase of such annuities to the time of settlement—we have accepted that. We think the amendment would have substantially improved the bill, enhancing its policy intent and encouraging the use of structured settlements in a responsible manner that protected the revenue, struck a more responsible balance between the competing interests and actually showed some understanding of the underlying economic principles that drive this proposition. I think it is a pity it will not be adopted. I suspect that sometime in the future it will be. But the most important thing is to get structured settlements in place; so we will not persist.
I will be very brief about the Democrats amendment. As I said, it was not our proposition; it was theirs. We supported it; we voted for it; we support it in principle. The government has argued that it cannot be made to work in practice—and I listened intently to the parliamentary secretary's explanation. I am sure it was a brief he was given by someone else, and he put it to the best of his ability here.
—He put it pretty well.
—I am sure that you think so. I do not hold him responsible for the quality of the argument. He was the advocate with a lousy brief, and we have all been in that position from time to time in this place. It does not seem to me to be too difficult to make the details work but, as I say, I am relaxed about the proposition. It is certainly not central to the principles that drive the bill. It is a peripheral matter and should not be allowed to get in the way of the central principles. (Extension of time granted) While I think it is a pity that the amendments are not being taken up, the bill itself and the principle underlying it are so overdue that we will do nothing to impede the passage of this bill.
Question agreed to.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I present the reasons for the House disagreeing to the Senate amendments, and I move:
That the reasons be adopted.
Question agreed to.

name: McMullan, Bob, MP
text:
—In rising to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002, I make it very clear from the outset that the opposition will be supporting this bill. It is a bill which amends the qualification conditions in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for taxation concessions under the Farm Management Deposit Scheme. The opposition has been calling for such action on the FMD scheme for some time now. For example, on 19 November, the Labor Party released its national drought plan—the six-point plan—and one of the points that we raised then was the proposition that there should be exceptional circumstances relief for farm management deposits. So it would be the height of hypocrisy for us, having advocated it and the government now having come to the party, not to support that which we previously advocated. It actually has in its origins something of the matter relating to the last debate, where we advocate a proposition, it finally comes to fruition through the government taking what we see as a belated initiative and so we support the initiative.
I will now look at some of the background. The FMD scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. Primary producers are allowed to claim a deduction when they make a farm management deposit and then, when an FMD is withdrawn, the amount of the withdrawal is included in their assessable income in the withdrawal tax year. This allows income smoothing by primary producers, to allow them to make provision for bad years out of the income of good years. As I recall, it is a principle that was established through income equalisation deposits in the agricultural sector and that has been extended to other taxpayers, and properly so, over the years—mainly in the period of the Hawke government—to artists, composers, performers, production assistants and sportspersons to average their income over a number of years.
This is a sensible principle and it applies not only to agriculture; there should be income smoothing potential for occupations which have an intrinsic volatility of income. In particular, the Labor Party have long supported measures to address genuine cases to this effect in the area of primary production. In 1992, the current Leader of the Opposition, when he was Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, introduced farm management bonds, which were the predecessor of the current Farm Management Deposit Scheme. He said at that time:
Income smoothing and the creation of reserves can be useful tools in risk management. Mechanisms such as tax averaging and Income Equalisation Deposits (IEDs) have important roles to play in financial management ... The Government will ensure that the entire package of income taxation and associated measures is providing both correct and consistent signals to farmers to encourage sustainable and efficient management systems. 
I think that is a pretty good summation of the underlying economic public policy principles in this area. It was our policy in 1992 and it remains our policy now. 
I will now turn to the substantive provisions of this bill. It has to be recognised that, through operating programs such as the Farm Management Deposit Scheme, the Commonwealth is forgoing a certain amount of revenue compared with what would otherwise have been collected. This means, of course, that we have to take great care to ensure that only genuine cases qualify for such provisions. The primary integrity measure in the FMD scheme as it stands is that, to be eligible for the tax concession, no part of the deposit is allowed to be withdrawn within 12 months. We are moving to change that integrity measure; so, while I support it, we have to proceed with great caution. I want to outline it in a little bit of detail so that, in any future debates, the basis on which we are prepared to make this exception is very clear. At the moment, the only exceptions to this rule occur if the owner dies, becomes bankrupt, ceases to be a primary producer, or where there is a transfer to another financial institution.  
The principle underlying this integrity measure is sound. The genuine use of such a scheme is for long-term provision for bad years. It is not about allowing artificial manipulation of incomes to switch income from the end of one financial year to the start of the next. Having said that, we have discovered, from the recent awful experience of the current severe drought, that this integrity measure has plainly been too restrictive. Responsible farmers who put money aside last year in reasonable expectation of the circumstances they might confront, and have subsequently been hit by drought, have been unable to access their money without a retrospective tax penalty. That was never the intention of the scheme. 
The legislation will allow the tax concession to be maintained despite withdrawals being within the 12 months, under certain circumstances—and it is important that we define these fairly carefully. Firstly, it provides an exception to the 12-month waiting period for access to FMDs for persons in exceptional circumstances declared areas; secondly, it allows part of an FMD to be withdrawn within 12 months provided the remaining amount of the deposit is $1,000 or more and is retained in the account for at least 12 months; and, thirdly, it allows FMDs to be held in accounts of any term provided the amount is not withdrawn within 12 months from the date of deposit. The third point deals with a different problem from the one that we are primarily dealing with, but it is also valid and we support it. I note that the changed conditions regarding exceptional circumstances and partial withdrawals will apply from 1 July 2002. The changed conditions regarding term limits for deposit accounts will be backdated to the commencement of the FMD provisions on 2 January 1999, because they are so overdue and have been needed for almost four years. 
As I noted earlier, the FMD reform plan is welcome, but it comes only after sustained pressure from the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for primary industries and resources on this issue. On 19 November they jointly announced, as a key point in Labor's national drought plan, an FMD relief plan for those in exceptional circumstances areas. Labor's policy was to improve the Farm Management Deposit Scheme by committing to:
Providing flexibility in accessing Farm Management Deposits to allow farmers in EC-declared areas to withdraw deposits within 12 months, without penalty, in this financial year.
This is almost identical to what has come forward from the government, so we are pleased that they have shown sufficient flexibility to take up our proposals in this important area. The proposed amendment to the laws protecting the tax concession for short-term FMDs is also welcome, but its adoption is even more belated than the EC proposal. According to evidence given to Senate estimates last month, the government has known about legal uncertainty over the tax status of short-term farm management deposits since July 2001 but failed to act. This was grossly irresponsible behaviour at a time when all farmers who had rolled over FMDs within 12 months of deposit since 1999 were facing potentially massive tax bills from a potentially unfavourable tax ruling. We are pleased that this issue has now been clarified through a legislative amendment, but it is overdue. We also consider that clarifying the conditions regarding partial withdrawals is a sensible extension of flexibility in FMD arrangements. Accordingly, Labor will be supporting this bill.
I want to note a concern—similar to a concern I have expressed before—regarding the costing information that has come forward with this bill. We continually find with this government that the House is having to make decisions without being treated to the courtesy of a decent effort to provide costing information. It is a very arrogant approach. Of all the portfolio ministers in any government, you would expect the Treasurer to be the one who would pay due attention to the revenue impact of measures and ensure that the parliament is properly informed about them. After all, it is the Treasurer's responsibility.
—He is not interested.
—Consistent with the increasingly cursory treatment he is giving his day job—as my colleague the member for Lowe says, he is not interested; he is merely waiting for the Prime Minister to declare his innings closed—we have seen an increasingly cursory treatment of the costing— 
—You wish he was not! We have seen an increasingly cursory treatment of costings of measures in his portfolio. For example, we had the extraordinary spectacle of a consolidations measure costing a billion dollars being dealt with in a mere 50 words—that is $20 million a word. Then we had the demergers measure costed before us simply as `unquantifiable', due apparently to the difficulty in estimating the extent of behavioural change induced by the measure. The nominal cost of that measure was put in the region of a billion dollars, but the government did not see fit to provide a proper account of this expenditure to the House of Representatives. So it is part of a continuing pattern of behaviour. What do we find on this occasion? It is quite extraordinary. It says:
... apart from a timing effect, the overall cost of FMDs in the forward estimates will not be affected.
But it is precisely the timing effect that costs the money. That is what is the cost to the Commonwealth. If we are changing the timing effect, we are changing the revenue. We are not stupid; we can work that out. You owe us the courtesy of telling us what the effect of that will be. It is precisely the timing effect that constitutes the tax concession—that is what is good about it; and that therefore seems to be a pretty flimsy excuse for not providing a proper costing to the House. The tax expenditure by the Commonwealth on this program is now very substantial. On 20 November this year the Prime Minister said:
As at the 30th of June last—
that is, 30 June this year—
43,000 Australian farmers had deposited over $2 billion dollars in the scheme.
I continue to quote the Prime Minister, who went on to say:
This reflects an approximate cost to the Commonwealth of $500 million in foregone tax revenue.
So if the government can work out how much the program costs overall and if that is driven by timing effects, it does not seem to me too difficult for the government to meet its obligation to tell the parliament how much the measures in this bill will cost. When the debate is concluded by the parliamentary secretary I would very much appreciate him giving the House, the parliament and the people of Australia the courtesy of telling us what this is going to cost before we vote for it. Every citizen would want the parliament to know what proposed measures are going to cost before they are voted on. We support the proposition; we are not going to obstruct the proposition, we are going vote for this bill. But perhaps we should not have said that in advance. We might have got more courteous treatment if we had held out, but that would not have been very responsible. We are going to support it, but dealing with us in this way does not encourage us to support measures in the future.
As I noted previously, on 19 November the Labor Party announced its six-point national drought plan which contained these FMD measures that have now been taken up by the government. In addition to that, we committed to changes to cut through the red tape, to help farmers protect core breeding stock, to address feed grain shortage concerns, to stop the buck-passing and squabbling that drives everybody so mad about Commonwealth-state relations in this and other areas and to get rid of duplication and target programs to help those in need. The government has made a half-hearted attempt to move in the same direction but it still has a long way to go. We would greatly appreciate the government adopting the rest of the national drought plan, not because it would be good for us—it does not make any difference to us—but because it would be good for the nation, particularly for the farmers and communities affected.
But we should perhaps not be surprised that the government has been tardy in acting on drought relief. After all, the Treasurer took a very long time to be convinced that the drought was even a serious economic issue. In July, when he was asked directly about whether the GDP would be affected by the worsening drought, he replied: 
... agricultural production is not a large part of Australia's GDP. So, the effect that it will have will affect that proportion of GDP that is made up of agricultural production.
You can see him waving his hand dismissively in the press conference and saying, `That was clever! I got through that question at the press conference very cleverly.' But beneath the veneer of clever acting there is no substance. He simply missed the essential economic reality—which has come home to him now—that the flow-on impacts from this particular sector are very important for the rest of the economy. Apart from the dismissive attitude that the Treasurer had in July to the profound social concerns for so many businesses, families and communities, he missed the economic point, which is his ultimate responsibility. By the time of the release of the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook last month, the inescapable reality of the budget numbers had forced him to change his tune. The MYEFO noted that the current disastrous drought is likely to reduce economic growth for the whole country by as much as three-quarters of a per cent of overall GDP. To give you an idea of scale, that is actually a reduction of one-fifth of the budget forecast growth for this year, or nearly $6 billion. There were people screaming out, trying to tell the Treasurer in July that it was a big problem, but he would not listen.
The MYEFO also said that total farm production is projected to decline by around 17 per cent in 2002-03, with much greater declines in grain production. It is clear that, by any measure, this is a drastic and severe impact on the national economy. But the Treasurer missed it. It is another example of that arrogance and complacency that led him to miss the slowly emerging train crash of the HIH collapse, the crisis in public liability insurance, the breakdown in corporate governance and accountability, the explosion in household and credit card debt and the clear signs that housing prices are rising unsustainably. In each instance, the Treasurer has either failed to see it or initially dismissed it and then, when it had finally become a crisis, he has acted belatedly. In each of these cases, a Treasurer who was concentrating on his job would have seen the signs early and headed the issues off before they became profound national crises. The Treasurer did not cause those crises but he failed to act early enough to head them off.
These days the government talks a lot about pre-emptive doctrines; it talks rather too loudly and rather inappropriately about them. Maybe it should concentrate a little bit more on some pre-emptive action domestically to head off threats to the domestic financial security of ordinary Australian working families. This sort of real domestic responsibility is very important at the current time. Questions over the investment outlook, along with the high level of debt and the weak budget position, leave the economy particularly vulnerable if the government's assumptions about the breaking of the drought and the strength of the international economy prove too optimistic.
It is a cause of continuing concern to me that, in the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook report, the government's projections about economic growth and its consequential views about the budget are based on some very risky assumptions. To be fair, they are very explicit assumptions—as they should be. You do not have to dig in the document to find them; the Treasurer and the Treasury have been quite up front and have explicitly stated what their assumptions are—and some of them are the only assumptions they could have made. For example, they have made an assumption that the drought will last only for this season. It makes no sense in an economic forecasting document to make any other assumption, so I am not in that instance critical. I simply say it is, however, a risky assumption. It is the only one that could be made, but we all know that that means there are serious economic risks out there.
The forecast about the international economy is certainly on the optimistic side of the collective opinion on how the international economy might go. I sincerely hope it is correct; it is very important for Australia that it is. The assumptions about housing are not only optimistic; today's figures make them look a little bit premature. With Christmas coming and Australian families under financial pressure—thanks to high debt levels and the high taxing policies of the Treasurer—it is vital that economic growth continues at a healthy level, so I hope all those assumptions come to pass. Even so, we will see the economy slowing. With all those assumptions coming through, it should start to pick up by next financial year. Let us all hope that is true.
