Particularly, let us all hope the assumption that this drought will not be long lasting is true, because it is having such a profound impact on so many Australians. 
I was recently out in the Dubbo area, in the Riverina and down in Mildura. While some of those areas, because they are based on irrigation agriculture, are actually still looking very green, out west of Dubbo there are some areas of prime agricultural land that I have never seen looking as they do. I have seen bits of Australia looking like that because I have been in the desert, but I have never seen what are renowned areas of great agricultural production in this country in such devastated condition. I have been in droughts. I grew up in Western Australia, and many of the farming areas are not so much drought prone—although droughts can occur anywhere—as very dry farming country. Yet, the area I saw was a shock to me even though I have been travelling in rural Australia for most of my life. Let us hope that, for human as well as economic reasons, the assumptions about the drought breaking are correct.
What I really want to emphasise in concluding, and in coming back to the bill, is that we have to have the Treasurer focused back on the job. He has to focus on applying the kind of whole of economy and whole of portfolio scrutiny he gets paid to apply and on providing the sort of economic leadership Australians are entitled to expect. Rather, he has shown complacency and is marking time. We continually see the `these other issues aren't important enough to warrant my attention' attitude from the Treasurer in all of those areas I listed earlier, and we saw it with respect to ethanol in the parliament yesterday. This bill contains positive reforms to the qualifications on conditions for tax concessions under the FMD scheme and, as I indicated at the outset, the opposition will be supporting the bill. While the government has made a half-hearted attempt to adopt Labor's drought policy, it still has a long way to go. I hope it will put aside its political preferences on drought relief and implement the remaining elements of the national drought plan as soon as possible. We are pleased to see this measure—one part of our six-point plan—adopted and we support the bill to implement it.
debate_title: <title>TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002</title>

name: Moylan, Judi, MP
text:
—I am pleased to hear that the member for Fraser and the Labor Party support the measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002 to assist farmers, because this is one of those issues that really deserves strong bipartisan support. But, as always, politics has crept into the debate, and I have to answer some of the points the member for Fraser made. In 1993 I entered this parliament and in 1994 I became shadow minister for small business and women, and I toured extensively the drought affected areas of New South Wales. At that time, the then Labor Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, had no sympathy for farmers and, in fact, made a public comment that they should make provision for these events.
I met with farming families in New South Wales that had been in the grip of a horrendous drought for four successive years. The experience of touring those areas and of talking to the men and women on the land will be forever etched in my memory. It was a very sad situation. Some of the women were going into the towns once a week, taking a shower and doing the family laundry because there was no water to shower or do the family laundry with. The women in towns like Casino and other towns in New South Wales had gathered together and done a roster so that the women had a place to go to do the washing and have a shower. They were keeping their water to try to keep their breeding herd alive so that, when the drought broke, they had something to go back to. There were many occasions when we cried together, and I was very touched by that. Even talking about it now brings out that emotion. It was a very emotional experience. 
I came back to the parliament determined to try to influence government—and the opposition at that time—to recognise that drought is a feature of the Australian landscape and that we really need to have a policy that is responsive to these events. It was not until 1994, when Ray Martin and the first Farmhand project really gripped the imagination of the people, that Paul Keating and the Labor Party were shamed into doing something to assist those farmers. I have to make that point.
As for economic management, I think our Treasurer has done an outstanding job of demonstrating economic leadership. The Treasurer, the Prime Minister, the Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister, and all of cabinet have, I think, been very responsive to the impact of this drought, which is the most severe we have seen in 100 years. They have been very responsive to the needs of Australian farmers and, indeed, the farming communities. It is not only farmers who are affected. During that trip, one of the things that was brought home to me very strongly was that it is not just the farming community that suffers during these occasions; it is the businesspeople and it is the families that live in the towns that support the farming community. The Prime Minister and the cabinet, including the Treasurer, have put together a very responsive package which addresses the needs of the whole farming community.
But drought is a regular event in Australia, and with the country in the grip of this drought right at the moment farming families all over the country are severely affected. This time it is not just in New South Wales; it is affecting my state of Western Australia. A drought of this magnitude really does highlight the importance of agriculture. On that point, I agree with the member for Fraser that it does have quite a substantial impact. With the Reserve Bank forecast of a reduction in income of $7 billion, it is not only the rural communities that will feel the effects of this year's drought. This forecast represents about one per cent of our domestic growth, and it is significant. Harvesting is not yet complete, but there are already signs that the yields will be substantially down on last year's.
The electorate of Pearce in Western Australia is not as hard-hit as other areas in Western Australia or other areas of Australia. But the further east you go in Western Australia the worse it gets, and some farmers have not even put in a crop this season. In parts of Pearce, the harvest is going to be well down on what it was last year. I have been ringing around talking to farmers, because in different areas it is a different scene. In some parts of my electorate they are having the best season they have had; but in York, for example, one farmer told me that he usually exports 2,500 tonnes of hay. This year, having just finished cropping his hay, he will export 200 tonnes of hay. That is a very big reduction. Some farmers are just starting to crop some wheat, and this year's crop looks like being down 60 per cent on last year's crop.
The shortage of grain is impacting on prices for stock feed as well. It does have a ripple effect in the community, and that in turn will affect other consumable goods and food products. Pig farmers in my electorate have sufficient water, but the price of grain is making it too expensive for them to continue to raise pigs. They are quite concerned about the situation. The high cost of feed exacerbates the plight of many farmers who run stock, and they have trouble keeping their breeding herds alive. Apart from the immediate impact of having little or no income stream now and in the immediate future, the loss of their breeders denies these farmers the opportunity to restart their operations when the drought does break.
Some relief may come from imported grain, which I believe is keeping the price of local produce at a slightly more affordable level. However, I was very pleased to hear in yesterday's announcement by the federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Warren Truss, that the Commonwealth will introduce a significant new measure to assist farmers to meet the cost of stock feed and to manage drought recovery. This should not be viewed as an expense but as an investment in the future, as it can take many years to develop good breeding stock. 
I was also extremely pleased to read in the Prime Minister's press release on the new drought measures that there will be additional spending on top of the $360 million that was announced just recently. A further $368 million has been committed by the federal government over three years. These are comprehensive measures that will provide financial support to farmers and communities hardest hit by the drought. These new measures are, as I said, on top of the $360 million that the Commonwealth is already expecting to spend in areas that are declared exceptional circumstance areas.
The government has decided to provide six months interim income support for all eligible farmers in areas suffering a one in 20-year rainfall deficiency over nine months—that is, March 2002 to November 2002. The Prime Minister has made the point—and I think this is an important point, because some areas may not be in this category now—that should the proportion of farmers affected in like manner in any other state reach 80 per cent, then eligible farmers across the whole state will have access to similar interim income support. Eligibility for the additional support available under full exceptional circumstances support arrangements will continue to be assessed on a case-by-case basis under the existing criteria. In addition, the government will provide an interest rate subsidy on new and additional loans up to $100,000, available for two years for stock support and drought recovery. This will be available to all newly eligible farmers in the areas listed, and there is quite an extensive list. A number of those places in WA such as Jerramungup, Corrigin, Kulin, Lake Grace, Coolgardie, Cunderdin, Esperance, Morawa, Mount Marshall, Merredin and others will be eligible for support.
I was also pleased to see in the Prime Minister's press release that small businesses in exceptional circumstance declared areas will also receive interest rate relief. Small businesses in affected areas face enormous financial hardship. Again, it has a huge impact on the town if they have to actually close down—and usually they never return to the town—so that is a very welcome announcement. These measures come on the back of other major announcements by the Prime Minister, who said in his recent press release:
The Government is deeply sympathetic to the plight of farmers and communities suffering in this drought.
He went on to say:
We want to work with farmers and communities in helping them deal with this drought. We will continue to talk to farmers and their communities on how the Commonwealth may support them.
I think the key to this responsiveness has been the consultation that has taken place with the Prime Minister personally, but also with the members of his cabinet who have responsibility for these areas—the Deputy Prime Minister in particular and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. As I said before, the federal government expects that, on the basis of current and conservative figures, exceptional circumstance funding will amount to some $360 million. The Prime Minister made it clear that, if more regions are declared, these will automatically be included and the amount will increase accordingly. In addition, the government will streamline the consideration of advice on exceptional circumstance applications to ensure that there is no unnecessary delay.
This contrasts with the lack of action by the WA state government, which is once again to be found dragging its heels in response to the effects of the drought in Western Australia. Despite the fact that it has been known for some time that the season was going to be bad, particularly the further east you get, the WA government seems completely unprepared for the adverse conditions. In a recent article entitled `WA wants funds to go direct', Chelsea Cormell said that WA farm groups are urging the federal government to bypass state governments and typically slow channels of exceptional circumstances to spend additional drought relief on direct grants. She went on to say:
The announcement by Prime Minister John Howard that spending could increase up to five times the current rate if drought persisted was welcomed by the WA Farmers and Graziers Association. But the groups agreed systematic changes were needed as states continued to refuse to participate in cost sharing arrangements and lengthy EC processes hindered the recovery of farming communities. PGA President Barry Court said under the current system little assistance flowed through to farmers because of State red tape and posturing. 
In a press release put out by National Party of WA representative the Hon. Murray Criddle, MLC, Agricultural Region, he accused the Gallop government of `incompetence by failing to assess the effects on Western Australia's economy of the worst drought in decades'. Apparently, the National Party wanted the official breakdown on the economic and social impact of the drought, but, according to Mr Criddle, all they got from the state Treasurer was a blank look. Mr Criddle went on to say:
... many parts of WA have experienced three years of drought but the (WA) Treasurer hasn't bothered to assess the impact on the State's current economic position, the effects on small business in country towns, or the social effects on regional communities. We took the bureaucrats from Canberra through the Northern and Eastern wheat belt where they met not only with farmers but small business owners struggling to meet high interest payments and overdraft accounts because of the downturn.
He continued:
We were delighted that the Federal drought package included Centrelink assistance for business operators and workers who have been laid off or had hours reduced but we are disgusted that the Gallop Government has virtually left the regions to fend for themselves.
By contrast, the Prime Minister and cabinet have been to visit some of the drought affected areas, have put together a package of measures and have responded in a very timely way to this crisis.
Apart from the commitment to exceptional circumstance assistance, the Prime Minister announced additional measures on 27 November. These included a couple of million dollars of funding for personal counselling services in drought affected areas. This is very important because we know that, despite the fact that the farming community are a very stoic, tough breed and can usually work through their problems, when people are hit hard like this over a long period of time—and it sometimes comes on the back of frost or frost comes on the back of a drought—there is a limit to what people can endure. I believe counselling services are very important in rural areas during this time.
Ten million dollars is to be put through the Natural Heritage Trust for environmental work in drought areas. This will target work that protects the land, water, vegetation and biodiversity resource base from the effects of drought, and will assist recovery. One million dollars is to go to a pest and animal management grant. This is an important drought management and recovery measure. Feral animals in particular can overgraze land which is in difficulty, and it does not recover or does not recover very easily. The government put $5 million into this year's Farmhand program and $1 million into the Country Women's Association Emergency Aid Fund to supplement the Farmhand program.
In addition, the measures in this bill will assist farmers in exceptional circumstance drought declared areas to access farm deposits earlier than they would otherwise be entitled to. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. These farm management deposits complement other risk management strategies available to primary producers, such as developing fodder and water reserves, financial planning and diversifying their production systems. Primary producers can claim a tax deduction when they make a farm management deposit. When the farm management deposit is withdrawn, the amount of the withdrawal is then included in their assessable income in the withdrawal tax year. Currently, no part of the deposit can be withdrawn within 12 months, except in circumstances outlined in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These include the death of the owner, bankruptcy or where a person ceases to be a primary producer or transfers the funds to another financial institution. Unless these circumstances exist, the funds will not be treated as a farm management deposit from the time the deposit is made. In recognition of the particularly tough drought conditions, the government seeks to amend this legislation to provide an exception to the 12-month waiting period for access to FMDs for persons in exceptional circumstance declared areas. That will allow part of an FMD to be withdrawn within 12 months, provided the remaining amount of the deposit is $1,000 or more and is retained in the account for at least 12 months. It will allow farm management deposits to be held in accounts for any term, provided the amount is not withdrawn within 12 months from the date of the deposit. The changes to the Farm Management Deposit Scheme are part of an important range of measures being taken by the federal government to assist farmers through one of the most crippling droughts on record. 
As I said before, many people are affected. This is the first time, since I have been here, that a government has given particular recognition to workers in these areas. I was pleased to see that the Prime Minister, in his press release, recognised that there will be increasing unemployment, even though it may be of a temporary nature. The government is keen to ensure that those who temporarily lose employment are kept in touch with the work force and are able to remain in their communities. Again, experienced work forces are important in farming communities. If some assistance can hold them together and get them over this temporary period, it would be a very important measure. This demonstrates that the government has done its homework, recognises what these communities need and has gone through the consultative process with people in rural areas to make sure that this package of measures to assist farmers will hit the right target. 
The government will introduce a number of special measures to assist job seekers in drought affected areas. These include establishing a Work for the Dole type program in drought affected areas to develop and carry out activities that have a skill retention and drought mitigation flavour. In drought affected areas, this program will allow job seekers access to job seeker training as soon as they become unemployed and will allow employees facing imminent retrenchment access to job matching services. I want to finish with the words of the Deputy Prime Minister in his press release of 27 November: 
The entire community believed government of all persuasions should do what they can to relieve what he felt would be a “summer from hell” for rural communities.
I completely support the measures in this bill.
debate_title: <title>TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002</title>

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—I am happy to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This bill deals with substantial taxation measures which will also have economic and social effects. They will also have an effect on the integrity of the tax system. These particular changes need to be looked at closely because they may change the integrity checks that the previous bill encompassed. The core change to allow people to withdraw from the funds within the first 12 months will take away the protection that was there in the original bill, so we hope that it is soundly based. We on the Labor side think that this is well based, which is the reason we put this initiative in play before the government came up with not only this bill but anything near the genesis of this bill. Labor's six-point national drought plan was put forward by the shadow minister for primary industries and resources, Senator Kerry O'Brien, in conjunction with the Leader of the Opposition, on 19 November. I will talk to the key points in that plan later in this speech, but first I will cover the second core point in this bill.
This bill realises what Labor put forward as a responsible opposition. We act as responsibly in opposition as we did when we were in government. When the member for Pearce commented, with regard to the former member for Blaxland and Prime Minister, that `Paul Keating had no sympathy for farmers' she was responding to what she thought was a political attack on the current Treasurer. It was ungenerous of her to put forward that political statement. I was there and I worked for the former Prime Minister at the time those statements were made. He had a bit of experience in farming and sharecropping when he was young. He certainly had experience in other areas of farming over a number of years, namely pig farming. We know that, day after day in this parliament and in the other place, the former Senator Michael Baume went through more than $300,000 of public money doing searches into the transactions and financial dealings of the former Prime Minister. How you treat farmers in difficulty is a question that Labor, when in government, tried to deal with in a responsible fashion, and I think we were successful in that. 
The current shadow treasurer alluded earlier in this debate to the fact that Labor put forward drought assistance plans while in government, particularly around 1994. Although they may not have been perfect, I have yet to come across any eternally perfect set of measures a government has put in place. It is always possible to redesign, to take into account changing circumstances, to see things within a larger context or to look at public policy avenues that are innovative and simply were not thought of by people in the past. When in government, our record in dealing with drought and the economic and social effects of drought on farming people was strong. 
The campaign against the former Prime Minister, and the campaign by the then opposition against our government, on these matters was reprehensible from start to finish. The member for Pearce's comments not only are ungenerous but they bring up the vast, dark stain that ran from one end of this parliament to the other—the more than a decade-long vilification of someone who gave his life and his strength to parliamentary life and to the service of the people of Australia, initially as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister. He had regard not to himself but to the public policy and governmental demands that were on him, as a minister of the Crown, and on the Australian Labor Party government that he was proud to be a part of and later to lead. That aside, Labor as a responsible opposition has put into place a plan not only for the current situation but also for the situation as it has been for a number of months now.
The government may choose to attack Senator O'Brien, as shadow minister, because he is from Tasmania and not from the mainland. He is currently from Tasmania. They might attack him because he is from Chester Hill, because he grew up in the electorates of Reid and Blaxland, because he had a city background—as I have a city background. It may be normal for the government to do as they have done in the past: attack people and say, `You shouldn't talk about any of this stuff because you don't actually come from a country seat or a country area.' But even people in the city have backgrounds. My mother's family came to Bankstown in 1925 when she was, shall we say, of tender years—about one year old. I think the last time I referred to this she corrected me and said that it was when she was about four years of age. They came from West Wyalong. Why did they move from West Wyalong? Because in 1925 it was drought affected. The severity of the drought in the mid to late twenties made life in the country impossibly hard. 
You need to reflect on the fact that worldwide—Australia included—the 1920s were a period of enormous economic growth. Despite that, Australia's level of unemployment ran between five and 10 per cent throughout the 1920s. In country areas there was no assistance; you could not get any help. Even if you lived in the city, you were in a position where you were right up against it. Things were a bit better than they were in the two other great droughts that Australia experienced in the 19th century. There was the drought in the 1840s. At the end of the 1840s, the combination of the drought and the fact that not enough people were coming into the country meant that country areas were depopulated, there was not an adequate country work force and primary production levels dramatically fell in output and productive capacity. 
A much more significant period of drought was from 1890 until about 1905. The great drought of the 1890s took at least until 1905 before we got a resolution of it. Combined with the four great strikes of 1890 to 1894 in a country that had no social security provision whatsoever, that made it hard for people from one end of Australia to the other to survive. There was not only a lack of work, because people had been thrown out by their bosses, but also a country that was ill prepared for the intensity of the drought of the 1890s. Why was that the case? It was because the period from the 1860s to the 1880s was the greatest period of economic development Australia has ever seen—particularly country Australia, because the harvests were incomparably good, as the seasons were incomparably good. Anyone taking up farming in certain parts of Victoria, in the Wimmera or in those areas that opened up as wheat belts in South Australia and Western Australia experienced perfect conditions year after year, season after season, for three decades, and they came to think that these conditions were just the norm. The drought of the 1890s taught them that the norm in Australia is that this is a country of drought, and drought can be extremely severe and extremely difficult.  
My great-grandfather on my mother's side spent his time in country Australia as an engineer building bridges and roads throughout New South Wales. What he originally saw—a country that had been highly productive and that allowed for a large work force—was eroded to the point where it was very tough to survive in Australia. That understanding in fact informed the formation of the great trade unions, such as the Australian Workers Union, who fought for farming people, for the shearers and for those people who provided the work forces within the country and tried to get them a better deal, particularly from 1890 to 1894 at the time of the great shearer's strike and associated strikes. So Labor policy has its genesis in a period of drought. It has its genesis in a period of fighting for people who have not got much behind them when times are tough. 
When we were in government in 1994, when Australia was experiencing a period of drought, we tried to deal not just with the economic impact but also with the social impact of drought. That was also done at a state level. The six-point plan that we put forward—a comprehensive plan released in summary by the Leader of the Opposition and Senator O'Brien and the more extensive point by point enumeration of that plan—went to the core problems that we saw as not being addressed at the moment. The politics of this situation and the manner in which Mr Truss, as minister, has dealt with it were fully addressed in the matter of public interest put forward by Senator O'Brien in the Senate on 13 November 2002. He made a series of points not just about the laggardness of the minister in this regard but also relating to the fact that the minister and the government had an inability to see the larger ramifications of what was staring them in the face. 
This bill is effectively a Labor bill because it takes up point 2 of this national plan. We said that we should improve the Farm Management Deposit Scheme and that the government should provide flexibility in accessing farm management deposits to allow farmers in EC declared areas to withdraw deposits within 12 months without penalty in this financial year. The key to that is that, normally, in setting up any range of provisions, it is important to keep the integrity of the tax system in mind. I am sure that the secretary of the department, in giving advice to the Treasurer, ensured that the original provision was there. Why? Because this is a case similar to capital gains tax. If you buy a lot of shares, our provisions state that if you deal in those shares within twelve months you are effectively trading or speculating in those shares, and therefore you should pay your normal marginal tax rate on any profits made in that regard.
After 12 months there is a concessional rate. It is treated differently now to how it was treated in our period, but it has the same rough effect. Post 12 months, it is a different regime. The regime relates to farmers who have opened accounts. According to the Prime Minister on 20 November this year, 43,000 farmers have taken the opportunity to open these management accounts, to the tune of $2,000 million worth of deposits. The way these accounts operate normally is that the person is allowed a tax deduction on the moneys put into that fund. Until this bill passes, and it will with our support here and in the Senate, when a person withdraws the money in another year—because it has to be at least a year on, and it cannot be a good year but a year when the person really needs it—then that person pays tax on that but at a lower rate. This is about the biblical good years and bad—seven years good, seven years bad. 
This goes to the point that the former Prime Minister made: in farming policy we cannot have the old National Party approach. The old National Party approach was: capitalise your profits, socialise your losses. It cannot be all one way. The minister at the table, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, the person coming after me, would know that his father and those other National Party members involved in pushing stuff forward—including Black Jack McEwen—fully understood that the bottom line in regard to this was that that was an epithet that could be tagged on them. It was tagged on them by Labor Party members at the time—and I think utterly appropriately. We have in fact seen it in a number of measures taken by this government—haltingly, almost blindly stumbling through—to actually attempt to bring back support from country Australia, to go over the line and press it. They are likely to go back to that policy when the farming community is in drought. We need a responsible policy with regard to this.
As important as farming is, at six per cent of our productive capacity, it is different from what it was in the 19th and 20th centuries. It is fundamental for people in provincial towns. It is fundamental for those communities that depend on our farming activity. It is also fundamental for those farming communities that depend on the feedlot industry. It is important for a range of intensive industries because, as we all know, the nature of farming has dramatically changed over the last decades. That being said, we say that responsible policy is making this change, with some care, if you have an absolutely exceptional circumstance—such as the fact that this drought qualifies as being as bad as we have had in 100 years or so, back to the great drought of the 1890s. The integrity of the system should be maintained, and that is where the Taxation Office will need to monitor this over time. In this period of great need, you need to modify and change.
We are glad that this idea we put forward is being taken up. The shadow minister has indicated that the government has dealt with one—point No. 2—and there are five to go. Of those five, there is a series—and I do not have time to go through the lot—that need to be taken into account. We have latterly had the announcement from the Deputy Prime Minister. A series of other measures will be looked at and attempted. These are the critical ones. It is no good just talking about them; we actually need to do it. The first point is to cut through the red tape. The second point we have dealt with. The third point is to help farmers protect their core breeding stock. That has been talked about in recent weeks. We were talking about this over a number of months. It is enormously important that that is done. There are practical measures that can be undertaken, and they are outlined in our six-point plan.
Further to that—and it is our fourth point—we need to address the feed grain shortage concerns. In late November, around the 14th or so, the Deputy Prime Minister raised the question of grain imports. There has been permission given—the shadow minister indicated this in his speech of the 13th—to import sorghum, because we just will not have enough for next year. What our shadow minister called for then was what we had in the 1994 period of drought: an audit of those feed stock grains. We should not just guess at the situation, not just take punt at what we might or might not need to do, but actively plan forward into 2003. Even with the hope that this drought will break in 2003, we need to forward plan in this way.
The fifth point is to stop the buck-passing and the squabbling. Today, the shadow Treasurer, and the shadow minister for primary industries and resources, Senator O'Brien, alluded to the fact that, if we are talking politics in regard to this, kicking the states to death for what they may or may not have done has been the game that both the Prime Minister and the minister in this House have played for many months now. It is not good enough to just belt the states and say, `Queensland hasn't done enough, so we'll kick them to death.' The member for Wide Bay, understandably, given it is his turf, might want to concentrate on that. It is not good latterly, because there is an election coming up in New South Wales, to say, `We've taken a fair bit of time—in some cases up to 264 days—to work out what the exceptional circumstances are in a place, and the New South Wales government is being slow.' 
The Commonwealth has a responsibility not only to process exceptional circumstances applications quickly but to stop playing political games. Case after case, issue after issue in these areas, that is what the government concentrates on. You are better off to just leave that aside and to take account of the fact that there is a coalition federal government and six state Labor governments. When there was one federal Labor government and six coalition governments, in 1994, we were able to work out a viable plan together, which was in the national interest. The sixth and last point is to get rid of duplication and to target programs to those most in need. Whatever the provisions are across our rural programs, we need to look at them and say: what's been there so far? We need to look at how they interoperate and how they mix, so that we can more effectively take account of what needs to be done and so that we can more effectively support the social situation of people in rural Australia. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002</title>

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This is a very important piece of legislation, particularly with the impact of the worst drought on record now affecting all of New South Wales and significant areas of other states. This bill aims to amend the Income Tax Act to provide an exception to the bill such that farm management deposits which have been held for 12 months or less can qualify for the tax benefits that they attract. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme enables farmers to set aside reserves in the good years as a tax deduction at that time and to withdraw that money in lean years and, of course, pay the tax at the marginal rate prevailing at that time. Normally, the tax benefits which accompany farm management deposits are available only when the deposits are held for 12 months or more. However, as I think any member of the House—even the opposition—recognises, these are not normal times or normal circumstances.
Our farmers are struggling in a horrific drought. I was interested to hear the member for Blaxland talk about his mother's time in a drought in the 1920s. My earliest recollection in the sixties was, as a very small child, accompanying my father to shoot cattle on our property in a terrible drought. It is a very disheartening thing to get up every day and know you are going to go out and shoot cattle. At that time, we shot a lot of cows that were simply unable to support themselves or their calves. Mentally, it is a very difficult and distressing time for farmers. This initiative by the government to remove this 12-month deposit requirement is certainly a very welcome measure. It is a demonstration of the commitment of the Howard-Anderson government to Australian farmers. But, significantly, it is also time to look at what our state governments have done. 
I would like to refer to the package of measures that was announced yesterday. I think that most members of the House would agree that these were sensible measures to ensure that, when the drought finally does break, there is a core breeding herd and that people are in a better position to go forward and start producing for Australia again. As the Deputy Prime Minister has said, each cow and each ewe can be seen as a production machine to first of all reproduce as quickly as possible after the drought. The measures announced yesterday for drought support include $368 million in one-off drought relief measures over the next three years. That is on top of the $360 million that has already been spent. There is six months interim income support for farmers who have suffered a one in 20 rainfall deficiency over the last nine months. That will enable all New South Wales farmers, as well as many farmers in Queensland, Victoria and other states, to access that. There is an interest rate subsidy for new and additional loans of up to $100,000 available for two years to eligible farmers. There is a similar subsidy for small businesses in areas that have declared exceptional circumstances, a recognition that those small businesses quite often suffer greatly because farmers simply are not able to spend.  
Finally, there is the establishment of a drought force. This is most important. So many of the employees on farms and in associated businesses in small towns find that the farm sector just cannot continue to pay their wages. They want to stay in the area because they have friends and family there, their children go to school there and so on, but they are generally forced to leave the town that they have worked in and to seek work in large cities. But, of course, when the drought breaks—as we trust that it will—they will be needed again; hence this work for the dole scheme, Drought Force, for drought affected areas. I note that the member for Riverina, sitting here beside me, was a great proponent of that scheme. In fact, she raised it. She was one of the first to raise this very worthy concept of keeping those who are so needed and who want to stay in their small towns and their farming areas as workers, and to ensure that they are given a holding pattern, if you like, through the Drought Force arrangements so that, as soon as the drought does break, they can go back to working on the farms and in the small businesses that they were originally employed in. There will be access to job seeker training for people in those drought affected areas. Certainly, the suggestions put forward by the member for Riverina have been taken up in a very worthy way.
But what of state governments? With this very generous and sensible package to ensure that recovery from the drought happens as quickly as possible and that people are given a sensible and measured helping hand through this very difficult time, what of the states? They have given less than 10 per cent of what the Commonwealth is contributing.
—Not Victoria.
—I said `the states' as a whole. I gave others the opportunity and the courtesy of hearing them out; I would like the same courtesy.
—The member for Dawson has the call. The member for Melbourne will resist interjecting.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Can I say that the majority of the states will be judged very harshly by the farm sector, and by those who make their livelihood in the farm sector, as they see the little that has come from state governments. They have constantly refused to commit to an enhanced exceptional circumstances declaration—in fact, some states have not even put in exceptional circumstances applications—and that refusal will cost them dearly. But today is the day for the Commonwealth to be proud of the drought assistance measures put forward and to be proud of this bill, which is going to enable farmers to access the deposits they have put forward.
I would like to refer now to the comments made by the member for Fraser, the shadow minister, in this debate. For somebody who does not ask a lot of questions in the House on economic issues, he was pretty quick to criticise the Treasurer. His criticism was that the Treasurer is not concentrating on his job. That is what he said: the Treasurer is not concentrating on his job. Let me have a look at whether in fact those remarks can be substantiated. Do not forget that we are in a very, very difficult drought—the worst on written record.
So what did the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook show? It demonstrated the continuing resilience of the Australian economy, notwithstanding difficult international conditions and the worst drought on written record. Certainly, the government revised down its forecast for growth from the budget forecast of 3¾ per cent to three per cent, which is all drought related. The cash surplus forecast for 2002-03 is still around $2.1 billion. Again, this is notwithstanding the unexpected and, in many cases, tragic expenditure, such as assisting the victims of the Bali terrorist attack, enhancing our security in the wake of Bali, a large program of immunisation in relation to meningococcal and a medical indemnity insurance package. These are not things that governments can generally foresee at all, and still we have a cash surplus forecast of $2.1 billion.
Yet the shadow minister has the gall to say that the Treasurer is not paying attention. By gee, you could not pay any better attention than getting a surplus of $2.1 billion in those sort of circumstances. It is a disgraceful slur in this debate to suggest that the Treasurer has not been paying attention. In the circumstances, he has done an exceptional job of finding the funding for very unexpected and tragic circumstances. I did not mention in the list I gave the exceptional circumstances funding as a result of the drought—$327 million over three years. What has been delivered as a result of that Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook is a lower unemployment rate than was forecast in the budget. This is going to mean savings of around $150 million. As I have just said, in the circumstances, that is an extraordinary result. 
The employment growth is forecast to be 1¾ per cent in 2002-03 in average terms. The unemployment rate is going to decline through the year to around six per cent. That is a pretty good result for somebody who, according to the shadow Treasurer, is not paying attention. As I said, economic growth in 2003-04 will rebound to four per cent. That is an extraordinary result. I think that the churlish remarks of the shadow Treasurer are just that: churlish and envious. The Labor Party, when they were in government, did not pay attention to a very serious matter. There was never an intergenerational report done when Labor were in government; they did not want to look to the future.
—Heard of occupational superannuation? Who introduced that?
—Order! The member for Melbourne!
—They were not interested in what was going to face our children in terms of expenditure in coming years. The Treasurer really is paying attention—
—You have done a report; we actually did something.
—Order! The member for Melbourne!
—and not just to the budget now under these circumstances but to the future as expressed in the Intergenerational Report. You are embarrassed, and so you jolly well should be. The people not paying attention were the Labor Party members. Let me tell you who is paying attention.
—The member for Dawson will address her remarks through the chair.
—Thank you for reminding me, Mr Deputy Speaker; I shall do as you instruct. Guess, Mr Deputy Speaker, who is paying attention?
—Who?
—The Australian people. Interestingly enough, the Newspoll survey of 2 December asked who is the best at handling the economy. Overall, 61 per cent of respondents nominated the government. And what is the view in terms of the ability of the opposition to handle the economy? Eighteen per cent of respondents said that they believed the opposition could handle the economy. Let me say who is concentrating: it is the Australian people. In terms of the Labor supporters surveyed, the majority—40 per cent—still believe that the government is the best to handle the economy. Only 37 per cent believe that it is the opposition. So the Australian people are definitely concentrating. Just as a point of interest, that also extends to national security—but that is not a debate for today.
The churlish, envious, small-minded comments about the Treasurer not paying attention and not concentrating are just that: small-minded and churlish. The results in the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook show that he has in fact not only been paying attention in these difficult and tragic times to unexpected claims on the budget through Bali, national security and the worst drought on written record but also returned in that period a surplus of $2.1 billion—and the record for unemployment shows that we will be able to bring that down to six per cent. What a result in these times.
Those who concentrate—and obviously the Australian people do concentrate—know who is doing the job. They know who is sound on economic management and they know who is sound on national security. They understand. I am not surprised that the shadow minister is embarrassed and comes in here with small-minded and envious comments. You would have to be envious, wouldn't you, of a government that, even in these difficult times, can manage to deliver the outcomes that it has. This is a government that can manage to deliver for farmers, manage to deliver for small business, manage to deliver on unemployment and manage to deliver reports for our children and the future of Australia. It is an exceptional result and the shadow minister has, I think, in a small-minded and envious way, tried to have a go at the Treasurer. Well, unfortunately for him, the Australian people are concentrating, will continue to concentrate and, I have no doubt, will continue to support a government that takes a measured and commonsense approach to the difficulties that the nation faces. 
Sitting suspended from 6.28 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.
debate_title: <title>TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002</title>

name: Hull, Kay, MP
text:
—I rise to speak this evening on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002 with great joy in my heart. This proposal, when put in place, seemed to offer too little to too few; however, it enabled our farmers to put aside an amount of money when their times were good in order to save for that rainy day—or that dry day, so to speak. The amendment is in response to the devastating impact that the drought is having on our farmers and on our rural communities. This widespread drought, now affecting 99 per cent of New South Wales and many other parts of Australia, appears to be the worst in 100 years. 
The Farm Management Deposit Scheme will be amended to provide an exception to the 12-month waiting rule for farmers in exceptional circumstances areas. Farmers in exceptional circumstances areas at the time the withdrawal is made are eligible to maintain the tax concession if they access the farm management deposits within the 12-month period. Under the current law, if a deposit is withdrawn within 12 months, it will not qualify for the concessional tax treatment. However, due to the current drought, the Prime Minister has announced an exception to that 12-month waiting period for access to farm management deposits for farmers in these exceptional circumstances declared areas.
The amendment to the Farm Management Deposit Scheme will allow farmers who have put away their funds in order to prepare for some of those bad times to access their money substantially tax free. Many of the farmers who put away their income within the past 12 months in the event of drought, flood or low commodity prices would never have thought that a bad year could arrive so quickly and with such devastation. The scheme as it is today was introduced in 1997 by the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. John Anderson, Leader of the National Party, and has been embraced by farmers, with one-third of Australian producers taking matters into their own hands. One would ask about the possibility of a similar scheme, or an extension of this scheme that is operating currently, to include battling small businesses, which are all affected by drought. Drought is everybody's problem. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme offers a commercial rate of return on deposits through 26 different financial institutions. The deposits attract tax only when withdrawn, and these deposits are tax free if taken out in poor seasons and low-income years. One could hardly say that this is a high-income year, so I welcome with great relief the changes to allow this bill to proceed.
In June 2002, more than 43,000 primary producers had heavily invested over $2 billion in the Farm Management Deposit Scheme. What an extraordinary feat it was that our farmers were prepared to forgo the luxuries and perhaps the necessities in their lives to ensure that they were providing for their own futures. It is often said in and around the chamber and in meeting rooms that farmers expect too many handouts but, when you read the articles and headlines in most of the newspapers, farmers are still saying that they are optimistic for a good season next season but that, if the rains do not come by March, they will really be in trouble. For goodness sake—as if they are not in trouble now. Week after week and day after day, the dust storms that have enveloped my region have been horrific, so much so that I have had families calling me from areas around Hay, Booligal and Mord to say that they put their children to bed with wet washers over their faces and wet sheets and then dry sheets draped around them just so that they can breathe in the evening and get some sleep. That is the type of devastation they are experiencing as they watch their topsoil being blown hundreds of kilometres away from their lands. They watch as their topsoil and swirling sands fill up their waterways. They watch as these dust storms ravage and devastate their already devastated lands and decimate their children's health and their livestock. 
When you look at the resilience of farmers, you see that it has to be pretty bad before they will get up and complain. Still they say, `This is not really as bad as it could get; it can get worse.' I do not know whether I would think that things could get worse if I were living in those circumstances and I was having water carried to me day after day by contractors. The irony is that, should it rain, we will not have that water because most of our roads will be impassable—so that lifesaving water will not be able to be carried by the contractors. Right across my electorate there has been devastation unlike anything we have witnessed. Dust storms are ravaging the rich irrigation areas of Griffith, Leeton and Narrandera, right through to Wagga Wagga and Junee.
In June 2002, more than 43,000 primary producers invested in this Farm Management Deposit Scheme, so they were looking out for themselves. The figures all show what a success the Farm Management Deposit Scheme has been and how strongly it is supported by Australian farmers. New South Wales farmers alone have made around 11,842 deposits worth over $547.8 million, with the average deposit for New South Wales being about $46,256. What a significant feat. As I said, I would be delighted if something like this could be extended to some of the small businesses in my electorate, which are feeling the effects of the drought significantly. They are looking at how to maintain not only their employment cycles but also their livelihoods in areas that have been so affected and ravaged.
The biggest investors in the Farm Management Deposit Scheme in New South Wales on a sectoral basis are mixed farming enterprises such as sheep and beef with $154.5 million, followed by grain with a $142.8 million investment. Grain, sheep and beef are some sectors that have been hardest hit by the drought—the majority of the sectors in my electorate of Riverina—with crops either lost or substantially down on last year. When you look at the devastating frosts that hit us last year and in 1998, you can see that farmers who are living with the elements of the land certainly do have challenges that they have to meet every single day and that they stand up to every single day. The struggle to feed sheep and cattle is experienced on not only a weekly but also a daily basis. The sight of farmers travelling around in their four-wheel drives—barely able to keep them roadworthy—putting out farm fodder and produce for their animals is a sight that one should always take notice of.
When we look at our producers being able to access their deposits earlier without losing their tax benefits we see that we are assisting them to continue that farming and that feeding. These deposits represent an amazing $600 million in tax benefits to our farmers—significant assistance provided by this government. When farmers take advantage of this early access provision, they will not be permitted to make any further farm management deposits within the same tax year, and that is only fair. If you are going to access the deposits and get yourself a tax benefit, surely you should not be able to make deposits. My office has received a number of inquiries from constituents wanting to know if there are any options available to take their money out early without incurring tax costs. My office has been receiving these inquiries day after day. Now I am very pleased and proud that I can inform my constituents that, with the passing of this amendment bill, they can access their deposit while maintaining the tax benefit. I am sure that there is no Australian who would deny the benefits going to these magnificent farming families.
This government has recognised that many farmers who put money away before the drought struck need this assistance and need to access this much needed, well earned and well deserved money now that times are tough. We recognise this, and that is what this legislation that is before us this evening is all about. By allowing farmers to access their farm management deposits, we are helping them to survive until it rains and they can get back on their feet. Some of our electorates are experiencing a small amount of rainfall today—but sometimes, when it is so minimal, that can be an unfortunate thing. People generally think that if it rains the drought is broken—but the drought has not broken; in fact, it will be a long time before the drought is broken. Unfortunately, a small amount of rain can sometimes be worse than no rain at all, because the psyche of the Australian people seems to be that, if we get a few drops of rain, the farmers have got what they needed and they should not require any further assistance. But we all know that that is far from the truth. 
Our farmers are working extremely hard. One of the qualities of farmers that continues to amaze me is their ability to keep going on with an unbelievable spirit. As I said, it has been reported in the papers that farmers are still saying that they look forward with optimism for a new season and that they feel quite confident that they will get through this. How many people would have that unbelievable spirit and resilience? To many people, it would simply be too much. However, our farmers obviously have it in their blood—they eat it, sleep it, breathe it and are committed to it. They love working with nature and with their produce, and their contribution to this nation is amazing. In my electorate of Riverina, I see the trials and tribulations caused by the lack of water that have been faced by some of my industries, such as rice growers and the horticultural industries right across the electorate who have had their water allocations slashed dramatically under new environmental proposals with a view to a water sharing plan with the New South Wales government. They are in very difficult circumstances.
I am fortunate enough to be working with the Pratt water group, who are looking to try to relieve some of these issues into the future. We are not talking about turning rivers back over mountains or drought proofing the nation; we are talking about the leadership of a fine Australian businessman, Richard Pratt, who has put forth his money—well in excess of $2 million—to assist me and my team to do a pre-feasibility study on the Riverina. We want to see how we are going to access water into the future and how we can have sustainable irrigation—not less irrigation but more irrigation—with a view to producing more for our export markets and providing much needed employment that is sustained by a very extensive, successful and environmentally conscious irrigation industry right across the Riverina.
All of these challenges are being faced by all forms of farming. Irrigation farming is facing its own restrictions, its own drought. People might look at the irrigation of the MIA in my electorate of Riverina and say, `They're water wasters.' They are not water wasters; they are producers for this nation. They are not wasting water that could be given to dryland and broadacre farmers; they are providing valuable employment, valuable production, valuable export and industry to help this nation and to help some of these areas cope at this time when they are drought ravaged. This bill is about helping all farmers, not just our broadacre dryland farmers who are experiencing dustbowls but also those irrigation industries that are experiencing devastating water shortages due to the cut in their allocation of water.
By allowing farmers to access this FMD money—which is their money that they have put in for a rainy day—they will be able to protect core breeding stock so that they can start again when the rains finally come. I was speaking with a gentleman on the phone the other night, and he said, `I have had to put off my farmhand, and my wife has had to leave her job in Hay to come home and help.' This family have not only been drought-ravaged but have had their income slashed so much that they have had to put off their farm help, and then they have had their second income taken from them so that they can both be on the farm performing duties to sustain them. 
I am so pleased and proud that the Prime Minister has taken on board the suggestion and has turned it around. With Minister Brough and Minister Abbott, he has turned this into an opportunity for Work for the Dole operations to be carried out on-farm. This is a fantastic initiative that will help farmers to have vital restoration works undertaken on their properties by people who are being assisted and supported with Newstart allowance because their usual employment has been terminated. I congratulate the Prime Minister for acting on this initiative and for moving so fast to have this put in place. I believe it will provide enormous assistance to those areas to, for example, repair fences and fence off dams so that sheep will not become bogged and lose their lives. Some farmers in my electorate are feeding every single day and yet they see their stock being drowned in mud because the stock cannot get out when they go down to drink at their waterholes. 
My electorate of Riverina is, like many areas throughout Australia, drought declared. Many communities are experiencing one of the driest seasons in more than 100 years of records. For Cootamundra, which has records dating back to 1889, this spring has been the third driest in its recorded history. For the two months of October and November this year, Cootamundra has received just 3.6 millimetres of rain. I notice that the member for Hume has just walked in. He is a long-time supporter of Cootamundra.
—We had rain today.
—That is great news. A Cootamundra farmer was saying that, over the last five years, he has had only one good year. There was drought in 1997, frosts in 1998, a grain price collapse in 1999, one good year in 2000 and frosts in 2001. It makes you feel, `How can I assist these magnificent people?' They are suffering more defeat now, with Shepherds Woolskins being placed in an absolutely untenable position by some of the issues that have surrounded them while they have been trying to run a successful business. The dynamic small community have rallied to help this industry continue to employ its people, and they are rallying once again to ensure that they can continue with this business. We held meetings with Shepherds Woolskins yesterday, and I am looking forward to ensuring a more positive outcome for them and for everyone in Cootamundra, because they have really done it tough over the last few years. With the very best of representation that they have received, one cannot produce miracles. One cannot produce rain and one cannot prevent frosts from striking down fields and their crops. 
This government that I belong to has made me very proud. This government has continued to offer support in the form of exceptional circumstances assistance, which is expected to be more than $370 million over the next two years. That is on top of the exceptional circumstances and relief packages that are already in place. The legislation to allow early access for these deposits is further evidence of the government's support for our farmers. In all, this government will have provided over $1 billion in assistance to our farmers. I ask: how much has the New South Wales government contributed to the circumstances of our farmers in need?
—Not much at all.
—That is right: not much at all. I call on them to stand up and be counted. Stand up and join forces; put your political differences aside and come on board. Travel around and look at the devastation. Feel it, experience it and do something about it. Come along with us to assist our communities—not just our farmers but our small businesses. We want to help our country Australians to keep living in country Australia. We need as much assistance as we can get. I say to this government: congratulations. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002</title>

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—in reply—The government would like to take this opportunity to thank all honourable members on both sides who have supported the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This is a particularly important bill, and the member for Fraser indicated that the opposition was in support of this government's initiative. We welcome that support. 
The member for Pearce, as always, delivered quite a thought-provoking contribution. On behalf of the government, I would like to thank her for reminding us of the importance of rural communities and the impact of drought on rural towns. This is something that the government has been mindful of in designing its relief package, including the six months income support for eligible farmers, the interest rate subsidies to farmers and small businesses in drought affected areas, measures to assist job seekers in drought affected areas, and a range of other measures. The government wants to recognise the contribution made by country Australia to the nation's prosperity, and members on both sides of the House have indicated their support for the important changes contained in this legislation. 
I thank the member for Dawson, on behalf of the government, for reminding us all of the further measures announced yesterday by the Prime Minister. Quite rightly, she noted the importance of the assistance extended by this government to those job seekers in drought affected areas. The member for Fraser, although supporting the bill, suggested that income smoothing should be applied to sources of volatile income. The member for Fraser, having been a former parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer in Labor times, would know that it is a basic principle of income tax that all income is taxed the same, regardless of source. This principle ought only to be departed from in exceptional cases, such as primary production, sports people and artists. This is a principle of basic equity and, for reasons of equity, such measures should only be adopted in very special cases. I think there is probably broad support for that particular approach.
The member for Fraser also suggested that there was inadequate costing information. That simply is not accurate. These measures assist farmers in extreme financial difficulty. Farmers who qualify for the exceptional circumstances concession are able to withdraw their deposits within 12 months of making them. However, the amount withdrawn is assessable in the same income year that it would be assessed in if the farmer did not qualify for the exceptional circumstances concession and withdrew the deposit just after the 12-month period had expired. For this reason, apart from a timing effect, there is no cost to revenue. After all, the bill only affects farmers who have had their deposits in the bank for less than 12 months. The members for Fraser and Blaxland referred to Labor's drought plan, but the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry stated the situation very clearly in question time today. It is not just a case of Labor being an apologist for state Labor governments; many farmers would get very little under the Labor package—at least, not yet. The coalition introduced interim assistance and predictive modelling, and the Labor announcement was two months after the government's announcement, so it was a question of too little, too late.
The member for Riverina, in a particularly thought-provoking contribution, mentioned, as she often does, the problems of small business. She is a keen advocate in her electorate for small business operators, and all of us in this place know that small business is the engine room of the Australian economy. The member for Riverina suggested that the provisions should be extended to small businesses. I want to point out to the honourable member that the government does have other ways of compensating the rest of the community. I refer to the Centrelink arrangements which establish Drought Force, a Work for the Dole type program. It also allows job seekers access to job seeker training and allows employees facing retrenchment access to job matching services. The point I want to make is that the government does have a broad range of initiatives to assist those in drought affected Australia and does appreciate the important contribution they have made to Australia's national prosperity. I think there is a broad consensus in Australia that those people in rural Australia who work so hard to make Australia the wonderful country that it is should be assisted by the nation as a whole in these times of adversity.
The current drought is having an immense impact on rural Australia. It is one of the most severe in the last 100 years. In recognition of the particular severity and extent of the drought, the government has decided that, in conjunction with a number of other comprehensive measures, it will amend the taxation laws to allow farmers in exceptional circumstances declared areas to access their farm management deposits without having to wait 12 months. I am therefore hopeful that the government will receive the support of the House, given that the relaxation of the 12-month requirement will benefit farmers in exceptional circumstances declared areas. Members on both sides do appear to be supporting the bill. 
The FMD scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. FMDs complement other risk management strategies available to primary producers, such as developing fodder and water reserves, financial planning and diversifying their production systems. Furthermore, minor amendments will also be made to the taxation laws to enhance the flexibility and operation of the FMD scheme. This is one of the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister on 27 November this year which are designed to assist rural communities to cope with the current drought. The initiatives provide additional funding to meet a number of concerns, including cash flow for farmers, pest control, environmental protection and community support for struggling farmers. The amendments will help farmers manage the cash flow impact of the drought and build on the significant funding already provided by the Commonwealth in managing the drought. In addition, the government will also streamline consideration of advice on exceptional circumstances applications to ensure that there is no unnecessary delay in the coming weeks. This is a very important initiative of the Howard government. The government appreciates the backing of both sides of the House. I commend this bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

name: McClelland, Robert, MP
text:
—The opposition will be opposing the second reading motion. We do not believe the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 is necessary. Insofar as it is pushed, we will be moving amendments in the committee stage to reduce from 12 months to six months the period of exemption the government proposes with respect to the right of casual employees to pursue unfair dismissal actions. That is the primary issue in this bill. I will explain the reasoning for the opposition's position. Essentially, our reasoning relates to a concern regarding the growing extent of insecure employment in our community, and casual employment makes up a substantial bulk of that insecure employment. Essentially, the government's approach is a one-sided approach of scapegoating employees—and, when we are talking about casual employees, we are talking about probably the most marginalised and vulnerable employees in the community—and claiming that the mere fact that they have rights is an impediment to employment and an explanation for lower rates of permanent employment.
We say that, if you are taking away rights from a citizen—in particular, from those who are the most marginalised and vulnerable—you have to do so with good reason. The government have not made out their case. In taking this approach of victimising or scapegoating these vulnerable employees, they are failing to address a very concerning trend in our work force—that is, the extent of casualisation or insecure employment generally. In terms of casualisation, figures suggest that about one-third of the Australian work force are casual employees. Casual employees do not have the rights of traditional employees, which I will refer to in a second. To give an indication of the emerging trends: in the last decade, 87 per cent of new jobs paid less than $26,000 a year and half of those paid less than $15,600 per year. That is less than the minimum wage, which suggests that a substantial number of the jobs created are casual or at least part time; they are certainly less than full time. 
It is very difficult to get a precise handle on what is happening, partly because the government has declined to conduct an Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey. The last one was undertaken in 1995. We say it is imperative to do that, because the emerging trends are concerning trends. You have to bear in mind that the whole work force seems to be fragmented into two tiers. In the first tier are those persons who have special skills, training or qualifications. They are engaged as a core work force. Surrounding that is a second tier, a peripheral work force. That peripheral work force is growing—it is now about one-third of the Australian work force—but those in it are engaged as and when required to meet peak demands of the market or seasonal factors, as has always been the case with respect to casual employees. That is a very transient or short-term underemployed work force.
Insofar as that represents one-third of the work force—and, from all indications, a growing portion of it—it is significant for two reasons. The first is from the point of view of what it indicates about the distribution of wealth and opportunity in our community. From one perspective, the wellbeing of people in this peripheral work force is quite irrelevant to the economic wellbeing of the nation—that is, we could have a very successful economy with these people who exist in this peripheral work force not travelling well, being underemployed and having incomes of less than $15,600 a year. But, if you are looking at it from the point of view of the long-term liveability of the society—aside from the morality that applies to individuals in that category—and if you are looking at it from the point of view of the society we want to create, you are looking at a society that is already very unequal in terms of access to resources and opportunities and which is going to become increasingly unequal.
To make that proposition is simply to state the obvious: if you are a casual employee or an otherwise insecure employee on a fixed term engagement, you are not going to get a car loan let alone a housing loan and it is most unlikely that you are going to have access to superannuation. When you are looking at how our society is emerging, if you do not have the opportunity to grab a foothold on the exponentially increasing housing property market, you are going to be left behind. Not only are you going to be left behind; your kids also are going to be left behind. On the trend of the work force, intergenerational poverty is staring us in the face. One-third of the work force is now in this category. I would accept and concede that a portion of that one-third in casual employment would probably be in second jobs, that they would probably be in households where there is a primary income earner. Nonetheless, a significant portion would be there as the sole income earner. They will not have access to the property market, nor will their children. If we sit down and look at this trend now, we have an opportunity to say, `We can do something about it.' That is the first thing, which is from the point of view of the society we want.
The second thing is from the point of view of the future economy that we want. I think we realise here in Australia that there is a fundamental difference between the opposition and the government on this point: the opposition continually says that it wants a high-skilled, high-paid work force but, if you look at the trends in the workplace, the government, at least for this peripheral tier, is quite happy to see a low-skilled, low-paid work force. When casual employees are in this peripheral tier, it is not in the interests of the employer to provide a lot of resources for training and upskilling, encouraging skills enhancement, because they are on the periphery. It is just silly from the point of view of an employer to devote resources to people who are a transient work force. We are looking at a situation where a third of the work force is not being provided with the skills that are required for us to sustain an ongoing, productive economy. Obviously, if in any endeavour a third of your work force—and that is what is suggested on the basis of the current figures—is not receiving that necessary training and upskilling, you are putting in place an impediment to the future wellbeing of your nation. 
For the purposes of scene setting, I would like to acknowledge those points. They are vitally important to a consideration of this issue. Why? Because this bill will fundamentally, in itself, encourage employers to engage casual employees for a period of 12 months rather than for a shorter period. I think an analysis of the propositions that I have put to date would suggest that it is in everyone's interests—clearly, the individuals, the society and the economy—for us to sit down and look at what we can do to encourage employers to engage employees on a permanent basis, not on a casual or part-time basis.
From the point of view of individuals, we have seen what has occurred. A well-known case recently was the metals casuals case of 2000. In that case, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission received evidence from a number of casual employees—as well as from economists—describing the effect of this insecure employment on their lives, their families' lives and their wellbeing. Clearly, in many instances they are engaged by the hour. They are there at 20 minutes to nine at night and they do not know whether they are going to be there at 10 o'clock. They cannot phone up to tell their kids when they are going to be home. It is at the whim of the boss, according to the demands of the workplace. They do not get annual holidays, long service leave or, most likely, superannuation.
—They get a casual loading.
—They cannot acquire property. They get very basic training at best. An interjection was made that they receive a casual loading. Yes, they get a casual loading, but it seems that that casual loading is itself not a disincentive to employing casual labour. Indeed, if you look at casual rates of pay, including the loading, they are still below permanent rates of pay. Why? Because of the very nature of casual employees, they do not have the capacity to collectively bargain. They do not have that security in their position to say to the employer, `Hold on. We're going to have a stop-work meeting to consider our position. We're not happy regarding the terms and conditions of employment that have been offered to us.'
—That's nonsense, and you know it.
—The member for Hume again interjects.
—I know, because I have worked there and you haven't.
—The figures speak for themselves.
