If you look at the rates of pay for casual employees as against those for permanent employees in industries, even considering the loading, their rates of pay are still below those that permanent employees are able to secure. Because permanent employees have the security, they have the ability to negotiate and they have secured those benefits. I say to the member for Hume and to the House that casuals are on the whole very marginalised and vulnerable employees. We cannot forget that, because what are we doing in debating this bill? The debate is about taking away a fundamental Australian right—the right to a fair go before you lose your livelihood. That is something we should be reluctant to do to any Australian, particularly those who are the most marginalised and vulnerable of Australians.
Again, what is our concern? Our concern is the very effect that it has on the society that we want to be and on the economy that we want to have, but in terms of the consequences of trying to get a rule, or at least a culture, in Australian workplaces for someone who has been a casual employee engaged on a regular and systematic basis with an expectation of ongoing employment. I am not talking about a situation such as fruit picking where someone may be involved in a rotating situation for a period of seven or nine months, with no expectation of ongoing employment in an establishment. I am talking about a situation where someone is employed on a regular and systematic basis for a period of six months with an expectation that that relationship is going to continue. The metals casuals case found that it was fair and reasonable that there be a presumption that those people be offered permanent employment. Bob Herbert, the Chief Executive of the Australian Industry Group, whom I have a lot of time for—I think he is a particularly balanced person, representing his industry group more effectively than any other organisation because of the balance that he brings—said in respect of the decision in that case: 
There has been no adjustment to casual employment for 26 years. Certainly, there will be some murmurs among employers over the increased loading rates—
I interpose and note the member for Hume's previous interjection—
but, in reality the AIRC ruling simply brings casuals to roughly the same pay and condition levels as their full-time colleagues.
I put that quote from Bob Herbert of the Australian Industry Group to my learned friend who interjected earlier. It is recognition that they were in a disadvantaged bargaining position. That is an industry group saying, `A six-month tour and this additional loading was an appropriate thing to aim for.' Indeed, that is what we say.
Now we come to the question of how we came to be debating this bill. We came to be debating this bill as the result of the decision of the full court of the Federal Court of Australia in Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC. In that decision, the full court of the Federal Court of Australia held that a 12-month exemption from the right of employees to seek remedy for unfair dismissal was not consistent with that provision of the act which enabled the minister to make regulations exempting employees from those benefits or that right if they were engaged on a casual basis for a short period of time. The Federal Court said 12 months was not a short period of time. In presenting their case—and this is significant—the government went into evidence using this argument that they persist with. It is an argument we will be prepared to engage in, to analyse the substance of it. I will do the best I can to look at it in the time available. The court specifically rejected evidence presented by the government that unfair dismissal laws are an impediment to employment. The court specifically rejected evidence presented by the chief government witness, Professor Mark Wooden, a research fellow of the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, known as the Melbourne Institute. I ask the House to recognise the name of the Melbourne Institute. The court specifically rejected that evidence. Indeed, the full court of the Federal Court said:
It seems unfortunate that nobody has investigated whether there is any relationship between unfair dismissal legislation and employment growth. There has been much assertion on this topic during recent years, but apparently no effort to ascertain the factual situation.
The court suggested how that could be done. Effectively, since about 1983, some federal awards have had protections against unfair dismissal. The court said, `Why hasn't a comparison been done of those industries or employers covered by awards that have that benefit for employees with those industries where there is no similar benefit, looking at employment trends in that sector?' No-one has done that.
In answer to a question on notice that I asked on 14 October—but that was answered on 3 December—the minister said that he took on board the comments of the Federal Court of Australia in Hamzy's case, asking why someone had not looked at this effectively. The minister said in his reply to me, `We asked the Australian Bureau of Statistics to look at the issue. They said that they would have impediments to using empirical data for the purpose and they suggested a survey approach.' The minister's answer refers to the 2002 Yellow Pages Small Business Index Survey. It then refers to a further study, done through the Melbourne Institute, which reported on 29 October 2002. I want to spend some time discussing that report, because we think the findings of it are flawed and that they were the result of a methodology that itself was flawed. This is of concern because we are talking about rights.
It must be said that Mr Harding, Assistant Director of the Melbourne Institute, acknowledged that there had been two recent surveys. One was the July 2002 Yellow Pages small business questionnaire. That survey indicated that 5.6 per cent of firms mentioned that the following were a barrier to hiring new staff: employment conditions, unfair dismissal, industrial relations and safety and health. Grouped together, they make 5.6 per cent, so we would assume that unfair dismissal itself, being a factor in that grouping, would be less than 5.6 per cent. That would be consistent with an earlier survey reported by Don Harding, the 1995 Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey, which referred to only 1.4 per cent of respondents mentioning unfair dismissal laws as a discrete impediment to taking on new employees. Mr Harding said, `We need to prompt employers on this issue to get their response.' With respect to Mr Harding, I submit that the prompting went further than was reasonably fair to get an accurate outcome of the views of employers. For instance, in the interviews conducted with businesses of fewer than 200 employees, I recall that there was an instruction to an interviewer trying to quantify the cost of complying with unfair dismissal laws. The instruction to the interviewer read: 
If response is that it is hard to quantify costs prompt by asking for best estimate. If response is that costs vary from year to year ask for a cost in best year and cost in worst year and take midpoint. If a range is given code midpoint of the range.
These are very broad prompts. Indeed, if you look at the figures obtained, you will see that the outcomes reflect such broad prompts. For instance, if you take the finance industry, one of the industries specifically examined, the businesses surveyed are broken up into groupings based on the number of employees: one to five, six to 10, 11 to 20, 21 to 50, 51 to 100 and 100 plus. You would assume, if that methodology were accurate, that there would be a consistency through those figures, perhaps even a sliding scale. But, when you look at them, they bounce around all over the shop. For instance, using that methodology it was found that, for businesses with one to five employees, the average cost is $45 per employee; with six to 10 employees, the average cost is $755 per employee; with 11 to 20 employees, the average cost is $0 per employee; with 21 to 50, the average cost is $348 per employee; with 51 to 100, the cost is $17 per employee; and with more than 100 employees, the average cost is $8 per employee. There is not even a sliding scale there. I suppose you would assume that the bigger the establishment, perhaps, the lower the cost. But, if you look at that trend, they bounce around throughout those ranges. 
Indeed, when looking at industries as a whole, the cost for an employer in respect of the wholesale industry is $44 and the cost in respect of the accommodation industry is $1,087. There is no logic in these figures. If you look at the prompt that I have indicated pushed these responses, you can see why there is such a wide deviation. Overall, the figure per employee went from a cost of $30,000 in one response to zero in others. Despite the massive variation, Mr Harding averaged out, by some miraculous calculation—adding them all together in an omelette and picking out a potato—the figure of $296 per employee then multiplied this by the number of employees and came up with the cost to the community of $1.3 billion. With respect, that is poor research. 
What are the consequences of that research? The research is used as justification for taking away important rights. Mr Harding recognised those rights in his report. On page 13 he says:
The central purpose of the UFD laws—
unfair dismissal laws—
are to encourage firms to engage in fair, and transparent human resource management procedures when dealing with workers whose performance is unsatisfactory. 
That is not something that we, in the 21st century, would think is undesirable. He goes on to say:
It is clear from the data that the UFD laws have caused firms to implement the two main practices that are considered to be part of good human resource management of poor performers namely, provide a warning, and provide an opportunity to respond ...
He refers to a table and then continues:
It is also clear that the UFD laws have encouraged firms to provide workers who are about to be dismissed with reasons ...
He refers to another table and then says: 
something that is widely viewed as central to fairness.
And it is: we are talking about the fundamental concept of a fair go all round. We are talking about taking away from very marginalised and vulnerable workers this concept of a fair go and their access to the right for a fair go. We would want to do this on figures, and I surmise that there is no way that Mr Harding will ever be appearing in a court of law to face cross-examination on his methodology nor on the figures obtained through that methodology. They just do not substantiate the propositions that the government has advanced. In fairness to the media, their analysis of the document came up with that comment. In summary, on the issue of exempting casual employees, fundamentally you are encouraging employers, by the very nature of this legislation, to keep people on as casuals for 12 months rather than make them permanent at an earlier period, namely six months. That is essentially the proposition that we are advancing. 
There are two other issues that I will touch on briefly. The first is the proposed exemption of employees on a fixed term basis. There have been decisions on this matter in the Federal Court of Australia, and as a result we are content not to oppose that exemption. The Federal Court has applied, we believe, practical reasoning. If there is a fixed term arrangement and that arrangement itself provides for a method of dismissal or termination of the engagement, the court has been prepared to say that it is not a fixed term arrangement but that it is an ongoing employment arrangement. On the basis of those authorities, we are prepared to accept that proposition. 
The other issue, which we will be opposing, is the proposition to lock in and index court filing fees. We are very concerned by the locking in of court filing fees and suspect that the government wants this to be an impediment to people bringing claims. The fact that someone cannot afford a filing fee is no measure of whether the claim is worthy. We believe that the appropriate way of imposing a filing fee is by way of regulation so that parliament can review that regulation and disallow it if they regard the filing fee as inappropriate. But to entrench it and index it, we believe, is an exceptional thing to do. From our research, there is no precedent for that occurring. Court filing fees are universally set by regulation not by legislation, and there is no reason to depart from that. We are trying to come up with a balance but we think the government has gone too far. (Time expired)

name: Schultz, Alby, MP
text:
—What we hear from the Labor Party is always predictable. From the time you walk into this place you know that they are going to come up with the same old diatribe centred on their ideological view of small business. The member for Barton's contribution was no exception to the rule. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 was introduced into the parliament on 20 February 2002. The bill was referred to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee on 19 March 2002. The committee received 30 submissions in relation to the five bills before it, including this bill, and held public hearings on 2 and 3 May 2002 in Melbourne. The committee reported on this bill on 15 May 2002. 
This bill will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to restore to business broad protection from termination of employment claims brought by short-term casual employees. I know a little bit about that, because I have been on both sides of the fence: I have undertaken short-term casual work and I have employed short-term casuals. I will come to that later. The bill will also move provisions imposing a filing fee for dismissal applications from the regulations into the act and will provide for the fee to be indexed annually in line with the CPI. The bill is aimed at assisting those businesses that rely heavily on the use of casual labour to continue to operate smoothly without fear of falling foul of the unfair dismissal laws. Adding more risk and uncertainty to the employment of casuals will have a detrimental effect on employment. There is absolutely no question about it. Businesses, especially small businesses, should not be deterred further from engaging staff, especially casual staff. It brings to mind a number of conversations that I have had not only with small business people in my electorate but also with others that I have dealt with in the past in my capacity as an employer working for a large export establishment and, prior to that, as a casual.  
When the unfair dismissal laws were first brought in, people were telling me about incidents that occurred in their businesses with regard to unfair dismissal claims that had been brought against them and how the system was being manipulated. On a couple of occasions some business people who employed between two and 10 employees had had vexatious claims made successfully against them. One employer told me that he had warned one of his employees about the employee's constant use of marijuana in his employment and about what it was doing to him in terms of putting him at risk regarding safety issues in the plant and in the workplace. Despite his warning this employee on a number of occasions and finally finding a quantity of marijuana in the employee's locker and dismissing him, he faced the consequences of the unfair dismissal laws. He paid out a significant amount of money and had to re-employ the person. 
As a follow-on this employer made a deliberate decision to restrict the number of outsiders in his business and to employ as many family members as he could in the interests of protecting his business and keeping it viable. That is an example of the harsh reality of small business and how unfair dismissal laws create problems for small business in the real world. I know that that is difficult for people like the member for Barton to understand, being a person with a legal background and coming out of the trade union movement. I have been employed as a casual and as a full-time employee and I have worked as a person hiring others, in a very similar situation. I can understand why he is out of touch with reality and, more importantly, why the ALP has this fixation on subjecting small business to unfair impositions. 
Businesses, particularly small businesses, should not be deterred from further engaging staff, especially casual staff. These staff help employers to meet the peaks and troughs that business demands, and that is the very point I am making. This government is about creating jobs, and that is the principal aim of this bill. A survey of small businesses issued by the Society of Certified Practicing Accountants in March this year showed that 42 per cent of small businesses did not feel that they were confident that they knew how to dismiss staff in line with the unfair dismissal laws. If they contact me, I can certainly give them some good information in relation to that. Yet 76 per cent of CPAs believed that small business did not understand the laws. The survey results confirm that understanding. The figures highlight the onerous complexity of the laws, with 62 per cent of small business and 81 per cent of accountants believing that the unfair dismissal laws require them to follow a complex process. The complexities of the law would be added to if business had to extend the minefield of unfair dismissal laws to short-term casual employees. This was a description used by the CEO of the Small Business Clinic in an advice column in the Daily Telegraph on 25 June 2002. 
There are also technical reasons for the introduction of the bill. The bill will exclude casual employees from making claims for unfair dismissal or unlawful termination unless they have been engaged with a particular employer on a regular and systematic basis for 12 months and have a reasonable expectation of continuing employment with the same employer. That will vary from industry to industry. In the Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants decision on 16 November 2001, which the member for Barton referred to, the full Federal Court declared regulations that had the same effect to be invalid. The issue in the Hamzy case was whether the exclusion of short-term casual employees from federal unfair dismissal laws was valid on highly technical legal grounds. The substance of the regulations was not at issue. The regulations excluded short-term casual employees from accessing termination of employment remedies unless they had been working for the employer on a regular and systematic basis for 12 months and had a reasonable expectation of continuing employment with the same employer. The full Federal Court said that they were not valid on a technicality. The Hamzy case was decided on a technicality—that is, the regulations went further than was permitted by the regulation making power in the act. 
Replacement regulations were put in place as soon as possible—in fact, from 7 December 2001—after the Hamzy decision, and they now operate. All the bill is seeking to do is restore the law in relation to short-term casuals to what it was assumed to be before the full Federal Court's decision. The full Federal Court's decision was an interesting decision. It was in line with many of the decisions that come out of the courts from time to time which the general public get rather irate about because they are interfering in issues and making decisions based on ideological views in many instances—as is the ALP. In many instances the courts are making decisions on the basis of manipulating the laws of the land outside what the public perceive to be their interpretation of the law.
I was interested to read the media release from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry on 14 March 2002, which was headed `12 month unfair dismissal exemption for casuals is essential for jobs'. This was a statement by Lyndon Rowe, the Acting Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. He had this to say:
Enacting the Government's legislation unamended does no more than retain the status quo that has applied for the past five years.
Let it be said plainly—if the Senate forces any lesser period than a 12-month exclusion for casual employees then the Parliament will have increased, not decreased, the burden of unfair dismissal laws on employers.
That would be a ridiculous outcome, given that the unfair dismissal debate should be about reducing the problems that these laws create for fair-minded employers.
The press release talks about the watering down of the five-year-old law and what it will do. It says:
For the past five years an employer could employ a casual and not be at risk of a federal unfair dismissal claim during the first 12 months of employment.
Quite correctly, it goes on to say:
The Government and the Parliament, not the courts, make public policy on unfair dismissal laws. Court decisions are not a substitute for balanced public policy on an issue as important to jobs as unfair dismissal laws.
I know the mainstream community would agree wholeheartedly on that in relation to court decisions affecting not only employment but, more importantly, various other issues in the community on which the courts have come under attack in the last 12 to 18 months. The press release ends by saying:
The 12-month exclusion is part of an established policy balance in unfair dismissal laws. For the past five years the Senate did not disallow this law, contained in regulations.
I think that pretty well sums it up.
On the issue of the follow-on from the Federal Court's decision, it is interesting that the ALP does not seem to grasp the situation that applies out in the real world, which is this: in order for a worker to be sacked, they have to have a job. The ALP should be concerned with job creation measures, not measures that add to the uncertainty of the unfair dismissal laws or that contribute to the idea that they are a minefield. The ALP obviously has no commitment to the wellbeing of small business—and I made reference to that before. The ALP is demonstrating a lack of understanding of small business and the need for flexibility to cater for legitimate business needs. I think that is the crux of the matter. This is clear from the comments of Labor, best summed up by Kim Beazley's comments in an interview with Maxine McKew on Lateline on 4 December 1996. He said that unfair dismissal:
... in the end has got nothing to do with small business—nothing to do with youth unemployment ...
That sums it up, as I said, very succinctly.
For over 10 years the casual exclusion has operated. It operated under Labor when the period in the exemption was six months. It has been a 12-month exemption since 1996. Business has operated on the basis that it can engage short-term casuals without invoking the complexity of the unfair dismissal laws over that period. The bill merely regularises a situation that changed because of a legal technicality. It is not about any alleged exploitation of casuals. It is returning to a situation that has prevailed for years. Employers have traditionally used short-term casuals to balance the peaks and troughs in workloads, especially where there is seasonal employment. ABS data supports this conclusion. Around one-third of all casuals do not work regular hours. Further, 44 per cent of casuals described their working pattern as casual relief work. That is absolutely right. 
The Australian Hotels Association had something to say with regard to unfair dismissal laws. And why wouldn't they be concerned about it? They are concerned about it because they employ more than 250,000 Australians in their industry. More importantly, they employ an enormous number of young people, who work on a casual basis to subsidise their income when they are going through university. Rural and regional hoteliers employ a number of people who are using casual work in hotels and in clubs to subsidise their full-time working conditions outside the home, to get those little extras, to add to the small luxuries of life that they enjoy from time to time.
As I said earlier, this nonsense—words about insecure employment, rights being taken away from individuals, the casualisation of the work force, the reference to special skills and training, the peripheral work force, the distribution of wealth in the work force and, finally, intergenerational poverty—used as an argument against the unfair dismissal laws, is just another indication of how the Australian Labor Party have never been in the position of balancing a profit and loss sheet in a small business or of lining up at the gate or at a packing shed, like I have, to undertake casual work. I might add that I have been paid reasonably well for casual work, except on piecework, where you had to justify the amount of money you got by the poundage or volume of the commodity that you had picked or packed on a particular day. It was not that bad in terms of the payment, because you were subsidised through the casual loading for holidays and normal award employment conditions.
There always was and always will be a very real desire by people who are in the casual work force, if they want to make something of themselves in life and make themselves totally self-sufficient, to continue to go to a particular industry organisation and work as a casual in the hope that, at some stage or another in their lifetime, they will be able to pick up a permanent job. They understand that. They do not have to have regulations from politicians to make them understand that. This is no reflection on my parliamentary colleagues, a significant number of whom, on both sides of the House, have come out of the legal profession but people do not like politicians who come from that sort of background telling them, as casual, ordinary, working battlers out there in the Australian community, how they should be acting as casuals in the work force. More importantly, those who are honest—and that is the bulk of them—do not go into the casual work force to make use of and abuse unfair dismissal laws. Most of them do not use them. It is only the slackers, as I call them, who want to make a quick buck and who have the handout mentality that we have in the community today who abuse the unfair dismissal laws.
I take great delight in having the opportunity to speak on this particular bill here tonight because I think the government, by introducing this sort of bill into this House, is going in the right direction in terms of making sure that we do have and continue to have low unemployment in this country. I can understand why the Labor Party are out in the wilderness: because they do not understand what is happening out there in the real world. It does not matter whether you are talking about unfair dismissal laws or any other issue in the mainstream community: the mainstream community knows they have nothing to offer and knows that the Labor Party are obstructing us in everything that they do. All the community is looking for from the Australian Labor Party is some assistance to enhance the good work being done by the coalition in reducing unemployment rates and making employers feel safe and secure in their role of employing people. (Time expired)

name: George, Jennie, MP
text:
— The Howard government and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations have determined that they are going to continue to persist with denying certain categories of Australian citizens the kind of recourse to legal remedies that the average person in the community would believe in as part of the notion of a fair go all round. I spoke earlier this year on the so-called `fair' dismissal bill, and tonight I want to make some remarks about the minister's Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002. Let me begin by saying that what the minister describes as being fair is quite contrary to the commonly accepted notion of fairness in Australian communities. 
In the earlier bill, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Dismissal) Bill 2002 [No. 2], the minister wanted us to believe that fair dismissal somehow meant depriving a whole class of employees of any recourse under law against harsh, unjust and unreasonable grounds for termination. That exclusion was to apply to anyone who, by chance, happened to work in a business of less than 20 employees. Now we are being asked to stretch our minds to believe that fairness will now mean, if the minister has his way, that termination without legal remedy for unfair dismissal could occur in a situation where a particular employment relationship existed—that is, where the short-term employment, as defined by the minister's bill, is less than 12 months. So we see a second attempt to deprive Australian citizens of recourse to legal remedies. I think it runs very much against the fundamental tenets of our legal system in Australia, which historically has been predicated on the notion that all Australian citizens are equal before the law. The battlers understand quite clearly the implications of the minister's doublespeak. They see it as being of Orwellian proportions. How is it fair, in any person's language, to deny workers who happen to work in a small business recourse against unfair dismissal? To deny to those casual employees who have an employment relationship of less than 12 months any recourse under the law is really beyond me.
What the minister fails to appreciate is that the import of this bill would have the most negative consequences on the most vulnerable workers in our community. It places those who are precariously employed, often in small business and often non-unionised, in the most vulnerable of positions. Of course, if the minister had his way we would see a double whammy, because there is, as we all know, a very high correlation between casual employment and small business. So it would be a case of double jeopardy for many of those workers who happened to be casual and in small business if this government were to have its way. We have to commend the efforts of those in the other chamber who over the years have maintained the line that the issue of unfair dismissal has to be treated on the basis of the principle of a fair go all round.
Back in 1995 the government's AWIRS survey reported that small business employed a higher proportion of casuals than all other workplaces—21 per cent of small businesses compared to 17 per cent of all workplaces. As we know, and as others have referred to in the debate on this bill, under the Howard government we have seen an acceleration of the trend to casualisation. Precarious employment is growing astronomically and job insecurity is rampant in our community. It is difficult to be precise about the exact number of casual workers who would be affected by the scope of this proposed exclusion, but a large number of people out of the two million currently casually employed would suffer the negative impacts of the government's proposals. It should be of concern to everybody in this chamber that Australia has one of the highest rates of casual and precarious employment of any developed OECD nation. The most recent figures I have seen show that the number of casual employees has grown from around 16 per cent in 1984 to anywhere up to the 30 per cent mark today.
I know from my own experience that a significantly larger proportion of women than men are employed as casuals. About 60 per cent of all casual workers are women. So it is this group of very vulnerable workers, predominantly women, who will bear the negative impacts of this bill. The intent of the bill is to deny the so-called short-term casuals access to federal unfair termination remedies. I think it is a terrible tragedy that this government is hell-bent on winding back the scope of federal unfair termination laws introduced under the Keating government back in 1993. I think it is to the great credit of the former Labor government and the efforts then of the member for Kingsford-Smith that working people, especially the most vulnerable, had protection at the federal level under a near universal regime regulating wrongful and unfair dismissal. 
It is true that, in accordance with the International Labour Organisation convention at the time, exclusion applied to workers engaged on what was then described as a `casual basis for a short period'. As we know, and as the member for Barton has pointed out in the debate on this bill, the 1996 changes to the regulations, which increased from six months to 12 months the period of engagement before redress could be sought, came to a head in the Hamzy case. The challenge to the validity of the regulations was upheld by the full Federal Court decision back in November 2001, but again the minister moved quickly to restore the exclusion. In effect, he is now seeking to have those regulations incorporated into the act itself.
What are the arguments that are advanced in favour of this proposition? We heard a lot in the earlier debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Dismissal) Bill 2002 [No. 2] that if we were only to carry the bill then nirvana would appear and there would be all these new jobs created. That is a great hypothesis but one built on no substantial body of evidence—which even the recent decisions of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission have made very clear. Then we were told that the figure was 52,000 jobs. At least in the case of this bill the minister recognises that employment-creating arguments would be absolutely untenable and unsustainable and so, to his credit, he has not used them. He cannot use them because, even when the Keating government introduced its reforms back in 1993, the reforms never acted as a brake on the growth in casual employment. The regulation of wrongful dismissal in the federal jurisdiction has never acted as a brake on employment growth.
As I said earlier, I think the real dilemma that we are facing is how we, as a nation and as a community, deal with the increased casualisation that is feeding the growing insecurity. If anything, the current exclusion of casual employees—that is, those who have been working for a particular employer for less than 12 months—is potentially open to be used in a manner which would further accelerate casualisation and precarious employment. It would open the door to the possibility of unscrupulous employers churning staff through their enterprises as a means of circumventing access to remedies for unfair dismissal.
There is a range of views as to why casual employment is growing at such a fast rate in our nation. There is no doubt in my mind that the whole tenor of the industrial relations changes—in particular, the stripping back of the awards system and the deregulation that we have seen both in the labour market and in the laws governing the employment relationship—has led to this very serious situation.
An analysis done by Mark Woden has shown there has in fact been a marked growth in the incidence of casual employment at new workplaces and firms. Mr Woden did not draw any specific conclusion as to why this was occurring, but let me put it to you that the accelerated growth in the casualisation of new workplaces and firms is the result of employers' deliberate decisions to circumvent their employees' access to unfair dismissal jurisdiction and to avoid the payment of many existing entitlements that apply to permanent employees. If this bill were to see the light of day, it would provide a strong incentive to many employers to churn and to continue to employ casuals for less than honourable reasons. In his second reading speech, the minister argued: 
The exclusion ensures that businesses have the flexibility they need to hire short-term casuals without worrying about dismissal proceedings if it turns out that the employee is not needed permanently.
If that were a genuine concern, employers would be able to use the probationary period exclusion as their defence. What is the defence for casual employees in the 12-month period? There is none at all if this bill is not rejected. There is no balance. 
I was sorry to hear some of the comments made by the member for Hume when he argued that the ALP are out of touch with the realities of life for people in the small business sector. I do not think we are; I think we are making conscious efforts to address the needs of the small business sector. We had a range of very constructive amendments to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002, which, regrettably, the minister has chosen to reject. You cannot have flexibility just at the employer's whim without understanding that, in doing so, you are denying rights to a whole group of Australian citizens who deserve the widest possible protections. There is no balance in this bill. While I and the Labor Party accept the notion of probationary periods, in our view it is unjust for Australian laws to be passed that provide flexibility and protection to employers at the expense of their employees, which is precisely what this bill seeks to do. Let me quote the minister's own words: 
After the court decision, as an interim measure, the Government made replacement regulations giving employers the widest protection possible within the parameters of the Hamzy decision.
The minister is unashamedly on the public record saying that the regulations were made to give `employers the widest protection possible within the parameters of the Hamzy decision'. He goes on to argue that the bill that he has brought to this House validates the operation of regulations found invalid by the Federal Court.
The member for Barton has well explained Labor's amendments to this bill. In essence, the amendments provide for a maximum period of exclusion of six months or for a lesser period of exclusion that is contained in an award or certified agreement. This position is totally consistent with previous practice under a Labor government. In the years of that practice, the sky did not fall in and the laws did not operate in any way to curtail the growth and flexibility that short-term casual employment provides.
Of course, the ability of employees to negotiate a lesser period of exclusion would provide unions with an opportunity and incentive to increase their coverage among casual workers by negotiating more favourable conditions for them. A strong argument can be advanced that, in view of employment trends—the growth in casual employment and the fact that workers continue to be classified as casuals long after they should have been deemed permanent—they ought to have the same rights as all other employees.
Historically, industrial relations practice has defined casual employment as employment that is informal, irregular and uncertain. A study has confirmed today that casual employment is no longer informal or irregular, but it certainly continues to be uncertain. A 1997 ABS report indicated that one-third of all casuals continue to be employed as casuals beyond a 12-month period. The same survey indicated that almost 50 per cent of casual employees surveyed in the study were in jobs that had lasted over two years, but they were still considered to be casual employees. `Long-term casuals' is a big misnomer that is creeping into the lexicon; you are casual because you are there on an informal, irregular basis, as historically has been the practice. Anyone who continues to be casually employed beyond a 12-month period is being employed in a way that circumvents the kinds of benefits and protection that come with permanent employment.
The end point of this argument could well be that you remove any casual exclusion on the basis that a three-month probationary period should apply to all. But, on balance, Labor's amendments to this bill are a midway point—that is, that the maximum period of exclusion be six months while at the same time providing the scope for improvements to the six-month exclusion through negotiated outcomes either through the award system or through collective bargaining or certified agreements.
I am hoping that the minister will give consideration to the constructive suggestions that have been advanced by the shadow minister, the member for Barton, although I fear that the minister's agenda is driven more by rhetoric and ideology than it is by real issues that are applied to real people. I do not think there is anything fair about any of the proposals and bills that have come before this House that go to the issue of the rights of employees who are faced with unfair or unjust termination. The Australian community believes in a fair go all round. Regrettably, on every occasion that this issue has been debated, the minister's approach has been driven much more by the political agenda than by an agenda that enshrines the notion of a fair go all round and balances the legitimate interests of employers with the legitimate rights of people who work for those employers. 
In conclusion, I urge the government to give serious consideration to the arguments advanced by the member for Barton on behalf of the Labor Party. I ask the minister to recognise that this government's repeated efforts to deny rights of equality before the law to Australian working people, particularly those who are most vulnerable and who are precariously employed, is not a principle that is accepted by the Australian community at large.

name: Baldwin, Robert, MP
text:
—It is with pleasure I rise tonight to speak to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002. Labor's disgraceful record on these workplace relations measures shows its lack of policy when it comes to creating jobs and supporting small business. Creating jobs and supporting small business are the principal aims of this bill. The bill will restore to businesses broad protection from termination of employment claims brought by short-term casual employees. It will also move provisions imposing a filing fee for dismissal applications from the regulations into the act and provide for the fee to be indexed annually in line with the consumer price index.
The bill is aimed at assisting those businesses that rely heavily on the use of casual labour, including tourism businesses in Port Stephens, Dungog, Gloucester and the Great Lakes areas. The bill will assist those businesses to continue to operate smoothly without fear of falling foul of the unfair dismissal laws. Adding more risks and uncertainty to employment, especially for casuals, will have a detrimental effect on employment. Businesses, especially small businesses, should not be deterred further from engaging staff, especially casual staff. These staff help employers meet the peaks and troughs of business demands. Put plainly: this government is about creating jobs. Yet despite all those commonsense and good policy reasons, the ALP is still saying no to helping small business on this legislation. We all know that small business is like the engine room of the economy. There are over one million small businesses in this country, and this is where around 80 per cent of jobs growth in Australia has been created.
By refusing to support these measures under fair termination, Labor is once again failing to support small business. The ALP's record—or lack of a record—for helping small business is an utter disgrace. During the 13 years of Labor, small business was hit with the worst economic recession since the Great Depression; record small business interest rates of over 20 per cent; high inflation; massive government borrowing and national debt, which accumulated to $96 billion in Labor's last year of office; record unemployment, peaking at 11.2 per cent when Kim Beazley was employment minister; record business related bankruptcies; and a $10.3 billion deficit left by then finance minister, Kim Beazley. Small business was left with an industrial relations system that was dominated by deals between big unions, big business and big bureaucracy; a centralised award system that restricted flexibility; and a job-destroying unfair dismissals law which, according to the Council of Small Business Associations, prevented small business from creating at least 50,000 extra jobs. 
Labor gave small business no protection in fair trading laws. Every time there was a call for fair trading reforms for small business, Labor commissioned yet another review. Labor had 17 reports, reviews or inquiries during its 13 years in government, but it did absolutely nothing. Labor consistently increased taxes. It introduced a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax, increased company tax, a compulsory superannuation tax, a compulsory training tax, automatically higher indirect taxes and higher fuel excise tax. Just look at what Labor did to provisional tax, which had an uplift factor of eight per cent in 1995-96. This adversely affected small business cash flows that should have been retained in the small business to assist with servicing of loans, increasing employment and/or supporting investment. 
Now we have a situation where the ALP has the chance to do the right thing by small business and really help them with unfair dismissal laws. But what is the ALP doing? It is doing absolutely nothing. It is not doing a single thing. It is not even giving the Australian public an alternative view on small business policy, because the fact is it does not have one. But even if the ALP does not want to listen to the views of this government on creating employment and helping small businesses, it should be listening to the business community, like the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The chamber is the peak council of Australian business associations and represents over 350,000 businesses. Let us look at what the chamber had to say about unfair dismissals. In a media release in March this year, the chamber said:
The Federal Government's legislation that continues to exempt casual employees from unfair dismissal laws during the first 12 months of employment must be enacted by the Parliament unamended.
It would be wrong and opportunistic for the Federal Opposition to hide behind last year's Federal Court decision to water down the 12-month exclusion.
Enacting the Government's legislation unamended does no more than retain the status quo that has applied for the past five years.
Let it be said plainly-if the Senate forces any lesser period than a 12-month exclusion for casual employees then the Parliament will have increased, not decreased, the burden of unfair dismissal laws on employers.
That would be a ridiculous outcome, given that the unfair dismissal debate should be about reducing the problems that these laws create for fair-minded employers.
A watering down of the five year old law will add more risks and deterrents to the employment of staff, in this case casuals.
In the interests of jobs, especially in service industries, that should not be allowed to happen. Such an outcome would fly in the face of public statements by the Labor Party that it is sympathetic to easing the impact on business of unfair dismissal laws.
For the past five years an employer could employ a casual and not be at risk of a federal unfair dismissal claim during the first 12 months of employment.
Those that advocate a less than 12 month exclusion need to explain clearly to all employers, including small businesses, why they intend to increase the right of casual employees to sue employers for unfair dismissal.
Employers totally reject the argument that a less than 12-month exemption is required because of last year's Federal Court decision.
The Federal Court decision invalidated the former regulation for technical legal reasons, not on policy grounds.
The Government and the Parliament, not the courts, make public policy on unfair dismissal laws.
Court decisions are not a substitute for balanced public policy on an issue as important to jobs as unfair dismissal laws.
The 12-month exclusion is part of an established policy balance in unfair dismissal laws. For the past five years the Senate did not disallow this law, contained in regulations.
There is no case whatsoever for the burden of federal unfair dismissal laws to be expanded.
If the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry can see this, then why not the ALP? The plain and simple reason is: too few of them have ever been in small business, have ever had their own money on the line, have ever taken the risk, have ever extended themselves in this direction. 
This is just one example of business putting on the record what they think of unfair dismissal laws, particularly for casual workers. But let me tell you of another. A survey of small business issues undertaken by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants in March this year showed that 42 per cent of small businesses did not feel confident that they knew how to dismiss staff in line with the unfair dismissal laws; yet 76 per cent of CPAs believed that small business does not understand the laws. The survey results confirm that understanding. The figures highlight the onerous complexity of the law. Sixty-two per cent of small businesses and 81 per cent of accountants believe that the unfair dismissal laws require them to follow a complex process. 
The complexities of the law would be added to if business had to extend the minefield of unfair dismissal laws to short-term casual employees. This description was used by the CEO of the Small Business Clinic in an advice column in the Daily Telegraph on 25 June 2002. So here you have two clear examples of businesses saying to the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens that unfair dismissal laws are not working and that there needs to be change. Small businesses are saying that to create jobs they need certainty when it comes to unfair dismissal laws. But Labor, the Democrats and the Greens still are not listening. Here is another example. The Australian Hotels Association said in a media release in November last year:
Casual employment is at the cornerstone of flexible workplace practices and, for industries that experience significant peaks and lows, it is an essential tool in successful business management.
The erosion of the flexibility of casual employment will simply hurt the chances of many young Australians to get their first break into the workforce. 
Industry uncertainty is the last thing we need at present. The only thing it can bring is job insecurity, while it will drive many employers to simply stop hiring casuals.
The hospitality industry has already been hard hit by the global travel crisis and had our problems exacerbated by the collapse of Ansett and the general economic outlook.
Employment is already down in our industry, which employs more than 250,000 Australians, and the effects of this judgement could be absolutely disastrous.
The final paragraph of that release said:
The Federal Government must act swiftly and must receive support in the Senate to fix this situation quickly before too many jobs are lost.
Business and industry are calling out for Labor, the Democrats and the Greens to support changes to unfair dismissals and to help create jobs, but they are simply turning away They are turning away from one of the biggest monkeys on the back of small business. They are turning away from reducing unemployment levels in their own electorates and from supporting the creation of jobs. 
When we look at Labor's record on creating jobs, there is no policy there. Labor claimed in the 1998 election campaign that it could reduce unemployment to five per cent, yet it produced no plan at all to get there. Instead, Labor offered 53 reviews and inquiries, as well as talkfests, task forces and meetings, as a substitute for policy. Under Labor, award wages for low-paid workers fell in real terms. Labor ministers publicly boasted about the fall in real wages, claiming it was a deliberate economic strategy. Over the life of the Labor-ACTU accord, even the low-paid workers suffered a five per cent decline in real wages. By contrast, real wages have grown under the coalition. 
Labor's record on creating jobs is just as abysmal. The people in Paterson remember the high unemployment rates under Labor. And what is Labor's solution? Talking, talking, talking and more talking—never sitting down and formulating policy on creating jobs, never sitting down with businesses to discuss what environment will allow for the creation of jobs. Labor's only plan is stalling on measures which they know are right and which they know will create jobs growth for small business. If Labor members opposite cared about the unemployment levels, they would support this bill that takes the monkey off the back of small business and spells out job creation within small business. 
As I said earlier in this debate, the problem is that Labor does not understand small business. Most of their members have never been in small business or worked in small business. They have been the slaves of the union movement. I would like to conclude by quoting a friend and colleague, Joe Hockey, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism. He summed it up quite simply when he said:
If you want to know what the Labor Party does to small business look no further than Western Australia. Small businesses are closing up. Small businesses are sacking people. Small businesses are not able to operate seven days a week to earn the money that is going to sustain their families and the families of their employees. The Labor Party is against small business. The coalition is for small business.
I do not know where the Labor Party thinks jobs come from. Government should be about only the planning framework, but it is small business that creates jobs and it is the owners of those small businesses that put their money, their investment, their risk on the line to create those jobs. If we want small business to create jobs, we need to remove the barriers. One of the greatest barriers put to me by the people of Paterson is that, once they have taken on an employee—and it has happened on many occasions—they have been marched off to the unfair dismissal courts when they sought to terminate that person. They usually terminate people because the work has disappeared and they cannot afford to keep that person on. So here we have the double whammy: they cannot afford to keep them on but they cannot afford the cost of going to the tribunal. 
It is not just the cost of attending and defending; it is the cost of the loss of a day's work. A lot of these people are small mum and dad businesses comprising one or two people, and time away from work means time they are not earning income. So quite often they settle just to get rid of the matter. If it were the members opposite and their money, their hands in their own pockets paying for this, how would they react? That is why the Labor Party cannot understand what this bill is about, that it is about taking the monkey off the back of small business and creating job opportunities by removing a barrier—a barrier that these people have never had to experience because they have never been in small business. They have never taken the risk and they have never put their hard-earned money and their family security on the line. That is the problem with the Labor Party. What we have here are union hacks, party officials and people who have never done an honest day's work for a living in their lives. I ask the House to support this bill.

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—I am delighted to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 after the member for Paterson because what we just had was buffoonery of the highest order. The arguments he put in relation to the background of Labor Party members are absurd. We know that the minister—
—Which small business were you in?
—Which small business? Do you want to talk about my Uncle Tommy, who ran produce stores in Bankstown and in Smithfield?
—No, you.
—Do you want to talk about my mother, Kathleen Cecilia Hatton, born in West Wyalong in 1924, who moved to Bankstown in 1925? For 25 years she ran the Bambi day nursery at 6 Meredith Street, Bankstown, where the Australian Taxation Office is.
—Is she in parliament? No.
—My family history is in small business.
—What about you?
—They were people owning small businesses and people working for small businesses. Sixty per cent of the work force in this country work for small businesses, including members of my family.
—Why don't you support it?
—You have had your go, pal, so cut the interjections. What we have here is a broad-brush approach by the government, inappropriately and inexpertly trying to run an argument about Labor's background in small business. I have discussed the matter directly with the minister and he said very simply that he is only talking about Labor's experience in the Senate. That is all. He has not canvassed the experience in here because it is not as easy an argument to make. He talked about Senator Barney Cooney being the only person with small business experience in the Senate. He was a lawyer. Not that Barney is not a good bloke, but he was a lawyer. That was his small business. Look along that whole front bench on the government side. What have you got? Farmers—either small, medium or large businesses—and lawyers littering the bench from one end to the other. Sure, some of them ran small businesses, but they were particular niche businesses. They are not entirely representative of the people in my electorate, which is littered with small business people who, whatever government is in power, are impacted upon by that government. 
I want to speak about the experience of people in the Labor Party and their families—because I would expect that the general context in which people operate is the context in which they grow up. They come to understandings throughout their lives, not just from their personal experiences but from the experiences of their siblings, their parents and their grandparents. Those things inform their childhood and their period of growth. Certainly in my case those experiences have had a profound influence. For 25 years, assisted by my Auntie Gwen and my grandmother, my mother ran a small business in Bankstown, a childminding business. It was not a business that demanded no skills or few skills or just a pleasant face at the door while you were doing things. The care and maintenance of young children—because it is not just care but maintenance and helping them to grow in place of the parent, because carers are in loco parentis—is an important thing to do.
My mother's experience was also as an Army typist in the Public Service during the war. Most of the experience of my uncles was in small business. Tommy was a manager in a produce store in Bankstown, which I worked in, and ran his own shop in Smithfield. My uncle Eris Dooner ran a shop for people in Bankstown and moved to Armidale, where he has been an extraordinarily successful businessman for over 35 years, running Armidale Home Furnishers. He has done exceptionally well. I mentioned in the House the other day another small business man in my family, Lennie Dooner. I could mention my Uncle John, who was primarily a carpet layer for the whole of his life but who also had a series of other businesses. He is well known to the former Minister for Finance and Administration, John Fahey, as a friend. They both live in Camden and know each other well. I could refer to my brother Anthony, who again spent a lifetime in small business, in carpet laying. He was originally apprenticed to John, then he ran his own business.
The nature of our work force in the past—the way people either chose to work for themselves in small business or to work for others in small business—in that more than half a century of my experience, was such that you could be pretty sure someone wanted to run a business and was able to establish it successfully and keep it going through relatively good economic times, taking the hits with the bad. For those people who worked for these small businesses in the past, the level of casualisation in the work force was relatively low. We are in another economic era now compared to 30 or 40 years ago. You have only to think of the period from 1950 onwards and what has happened to the structure of the work force and the impacts of that changed structure to determine what response is necessary from this House and the approach that needs to be taken. Through the eighties and nineties, the pressures to casualise the work force were very strong. Labor's approach, in government and out, is that, if you have massive structural change and massive institutional change in the economy, you had better have some answers as to how you accommodate that. We have realised that casualisation of the work force is a significant matter.
When you step outside this building when we close down this joint from 11 o'clock tonight, you will be lucky to find six Comcar drivers who are permanently employed. A couple of years ago, you would have come across 12 of them. If you go back a couple more years, there were 23. Prior to that, when we were in government—and our lot are not without sin in terms of what we did to belt Comcar around the head—there was a strong history of permanent employment. It is not so now. There are six permanent drivers in Canberra, six in Sydney, six in Melbourne and six in Brisbane, and we will no doubt get to a point when there will be none. The people who work just outside this place for Comcar have been casualised. The government have said, `We don't need the services all the time.' They have run a campaign within and outside Comcar to say, `We don't need all of that; we just need you as and when we need you—on call.' Apart from those who are employed on a permanent basis, those who are employed on a casual basis will be affected by this bill. If they do not get a guernsey for more than six months—or for the legislative bottom of 12 months—they could be in a position where, overnight, they get the bullet, and they will have no recourse. 
The shadow minister ran a series of arguments. He has run them previously with regard to other bills we have had before us. This bill had its genesis in February 2002. Before tonight we have had only three people talk on the bill: one, the minister; two, the member for Grey, I think, in a cognate debate in about May; and, three, in June the member for Fowler was able to speak. So we have had the minister and a couple of other people. Tonight we have this one piece of legislation which deals with part of what the government seeks to achieve, and we know the whole box and dice that the government tried to get through under the member for Flinders. We know that this government are all about dismemberment; that is, dismemberment of the original Workplace Relations Act into 12 different bits. They have run one bit through—the `unfair dismissals' which they turned into `fair dismissals'. That is the Orwellian doublespeak that underlies most of this legislation: turning something that is into something that should be perceived as that which it is not. They have run a series of bills to try to get elements of the original package through, and they have not succeeded.
Why haven't they got Labor Party support, Democrats support or Greens support for what they want to do here? It is because there is a fundamental recognition that, if the work force is fundamentally changed, if you cannot go outside and find more than half a dozen permanently employed Comcar people, there is a basic structural change. You might find that, in the other departments—in, say, Joint House—people have been casualised or are under the threat of casualisation because of increasing changes. Walk out the door and down to DFAT and to the other government departments around the place; you will find that the idea that you should contract out to those outside has had a great run since 1996. The impact of contracting out is that permanent jobs in the federal Public Service are lost to private industry. What often happens when you contract out—which is the normal way of doing things now—is that people who are casualised, who are in a dependent relationship for a short period of time, get the work. We have seen this move right through industry.
You can understand the normal economic and the cultural imperatives that move business—small, medium and large—towards casualisation. It is not as if any of this is new. Through the eighties and nineties the moves were very strong, but those moves have been validated time and time again by this government since 1996. The underlying rationale is that the cost of holding employees is too high. Manufacturers in the seventies and eighties said, `All of that is too hard, so we'll just whip off to Malaysia or Indonesia and set up a factory there because you don't have to worry about conditions like long service leave, super or anything else. You can pay low wages and you can run it that way.' We know that, in the globalisation model, that has happened with almost every major advanced manufacturing country on the planet. They have sought low wages and few conditions and they have continued to build the strength of their economies on transferring labour to countries where costs are low.
Given that there has been a strong movement towards that, the dismemberment of people's expectations of their employment has happened in the community at large. For a member of parliament—and it is not the most secure job on the planet—at least the tenure is, if we run three years, three years. There is that possibility. But it is different for people who are working for us as casual Comcar drivers or for people who have been turfed out of CSIRO. The driver I had the other day had been in CSIRO for 25 years, and he is out of there because they have made adjustments and they have cut down. One thousand people have been thrown out of CSIRO by this government latterly—
—They haven't. They are increasing their numbers.
—Hang on, Minister. I will answer you. Rather than have the minister interjecting, I would be very grateful if you could protect me from him, Mr Deputy Speaker. 
 (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The minister will cease interjecting and the honourable member for Blaxland will ignore the interjections.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The minister and his government are attempting to play catch-up. They knocked off more than 1,000 jobs in CSIRO. The government's innovation statement was an attempt by the Prime Minister in particular to gather to himself the chief government scientist and the scientific community around Australia. It was a desperate act to grab an agenda won from the Labor Party. We were out there before with a forward looking scientific agenda to try to repair the damage that has been done by this government to the scientific institutions in this country. We did this to repair the damage done not only to CSIRO but also to our other government departments with research and development backing, including to some CRCs that have been knocked over—although generally they have been protected—and to repair damage done to a range of industries by the government thinking they should deal themselves out of the game.
One of the ways of cutting their costs is to offload people. They have decided that science and innovation is fashionable. They have decided to increase the numbers because they flattened them in the first place—in 1996, 1997 and 1998—to achieve major budget savings. We have a government that is in the business of outsourcing, a government that is in the business of casualising and a government that is in the business of ensuring that that mode of operation continues. It leaves employees in the uncertain position of not knowing where the next job is coming from, how they are going to support themselves and their families or even whether they can put together a family in the first place. They have to juggle a series of different casual jobs which might run from a week to two weeks or from three months to six months, and they have to put together a package of them because finding permanent work on a full-time basis is not as easy as it was in the past.
The situation opening up for people in the 1960s and the 1970s—when I left school—was a paradise in work terms compared with what people face now, because there was still the certainty that you would be able to run with whatever you finally picked up. In the period prior to that we had the whole apprenticeship experience, with people aged 14, 16 or 17 changing careers, doing different things and then locking themselves into a career. All of that has gone. We know that, we accept it and we have to adjust to it. But we also have to accept the fact that if the economic forces are such that the permanent jobs are casualised down then you need to take that into account. The brutality of an ideological approach which says, `If you happen to be forced into a position where you've got a casual job, you will have no protections' is of no use, and that is what the explanatory memorandum lays out. That is what it says in the outline of this bill; that is what it says in schedule 1.
Let us look at who is affected by this: employees engaged for a specified period of time—there are plenty of those short-term contracts around, and a hell of a lot since 1996 compared with the number prior to 1996; employees engaged for a specified task; employees who are on probation, as long as the length of probation is three months or less or reasonable having regard to the particular employment; casual employees engaged for a short period, short-term casuals—maybe some of those Comcar drives outside; trainees who are employed under particular types of traineeship agreements or who are employed under a traineeship for a specified period; and non-award employees who earn more than a particular rate established in the Workplace Relations Regulations. That list corresponds to the list of employees currently excluded from the operation of the termination of employment provisions by regulation 30B—and so on.
That is the hit list. They are people who, as a result of this legislation, are going to be determined to try to react to three cases. The first is Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants, and the Federal Court appeal in relation to that case. The second is the metals case before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in 2000. That was a very interesting case, and it has not got any broader than that. The shadow minister detailed part of this case in his speech. The decision by the commission brought up to date the situation of casuals within the metals industry. It was pretty much out of date—more than a quarter of a century. Where did it bring them up to? This is not in terms of what any arbitration commissioner said; not in terms of what any Labor politician, either backbencher or shadow minister, said. What did Mr Bob Herbert, from the AIG, have to say? He is the most influential spokesman in the metals industry, from the employers side, that you could find. He said: 
There has been no adjustment to casual employment for 26 years. Certainly, there will be some murmurs among employers over the increased loading rates but, in reality the AIRC ruling simply brings casuals to roughly the same pay and condition levels as their full-time colleagues.
You might ask what is wrong with that. If, after a quarter of a century, you are going to bring them up to reasonable parity, what is wrong with that—unless you think they should be in a `Thailandised' state; unless you think they should be battered down in terms of the conditions available to them? When the current Prime Minister was Treasurer of the Commonwealth—as he was in 1974, and in 1977-78 after the death of Phillip Lynch, and he remained Treasurer until 1983, when the Liberals were flicked—he actually had the trifecta: double digit unemployment, interest rates and inflation. No Labor Treasurer has ever achieved that trifecta. We might have had one or two, but we did not get all three. This bloke has spent his entire prime ministership running away from that. Question time after question time the Treasurer slyly alludes to Labor's record, but it is really a belt at the Prime Minister, who is attempting to assuage his conscience over what he has done.
Having a detrimental impact on employment in small business or across industry is not a good thing. You cannot escape the economic cycles. We have been pretty good at that recently, because the foundation laid by Labor in entirely reconstructing this economy in the 1980s and 1990s has been incredibly strong. But it is not good enough to distort the record of Labor's employment achievements. The member for Paterson did that in this House; it is the one thing I have not alluded to in terms of what he did. It is an entire distortion to argue that Labor's record in that regard is poor. Equally, time and time again following his ministers, there are attempts to make an argument that Labor brutalised people in terms of their real wages.
There was an accord. There was an agreement that if you were going to create more jobs then you needed to spread the load and the pain. That basic push put Labor in a position where we could create a record number of jobs, far beyond what this lot has done. And this government has created far more casual jobs than Labor did relatively. We have a proud record in regard to that. We have a proud record in sensitively handling the issue of casualisation and trying to make sure that people were not belted into the ground. We were also willing to face reality and not drill people through the head when it came to the question of small business and the difficulty people had with unfair dismissals. The original legislation was changed; it was dramatically modified. This government's legislation, effectively, is no different. (Time expired)

name: Bishop, Julie, MP
text:
—I note the member for Blaxland is still in the House. I wonder how the businesses owned by the member for Blaxland's relations would have coped with an unfair dismissal claim if they had employed casuals? My parents run a very small orchard; they have for many decades. They grow cherries, and the cherry season is very short—perhaps a couple of weeks. For decades, they have employed casual workers. Usually, it turns out that it is the first job a person has ever had. In fact, since the Second World War, they have employed waves of new migrants to this country on a casual basis, and it has often been the first job that those people have had in Australia. My parents are very proud of that fact. They still do employ many new migrants to this country on a casual basis in the cherry picking season in the Adelaide Hills. But I know that, if they were subjected to a dismissal claims regime, they would not employ anyone; they would do it themselves. My father is 79 and my mother is 73, but they would do it themselves. 
—They must be pretty agile.
—They are very agile. So who loses? They would lose, of course, but so would the workers; so would these waves of new migrants who have come to Australia and who are employed, probably for the first time, in the Adelaide Hills, picking cherries. We are talking about winners and losers here, and I am trying to find out who is the winner.
Let us look at the bill that is before the House tonight. I believe the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 is another legislative instrument of the Howard government that is intended to achieve the dual objectives of more jobs and better pay for Australian workers. Six years after the Liberal Party re-entered federal government, the benefits of workplace relations reform are obvious. Over 950,600 new jobs have been created. More than 9.3 million Australians now have a job. The unemployment rate has crashed to a seasonally adjusted six per cent nationally, the latest figures being at their lowest level in two years, while the participation rate is at a historically high level. Unfair dismissal claims have fallen by 48 per cent as a result of three-month probation periods on new employees and restrictions on unscrupulous lawyers. Real wages for the lowest paid workers have risen by nearly nine per cent, and industrial disputation has fallen by a third. In the further pursuit of these objectives, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 amends the Workplace Relations Act so as to ensure that the laws concerning the termination of employment do not act as a disadvantage to Australian businesses or as a disincentive to the employment of Australian workers. As such, it is legislation that will be of obvious benefit to Australian businesses, their employees and the unemployed who so desperately want the reward, both financial and moral, of work.
The specific spur for this bill was a decision taken by the Federal Court in November 2001 to rule as invalid regulations excluding short-term casual employees—the sort of people my parents employ—from making unfair dismissal claims. The basis of this Federal Court decision, in the case of Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC, was an interpretation of the breadth of the regulation making power of the Workplace Relations Act. As a consequence, the longstanding practice by which casual employees were unable to access the dismissal claims system—unless their employment was on a regular and systematic basis for a period of at least 12 months and the employee in question had a reasonable expectation of continuing work with that same employer—was threatened. In turn, a significant barrier to the employment of short-term casual workers was inadvertently raised by the court, to the detriment of those seeking this kind of flexible work and the employers who wish to employ them. This is of particular importance, given the increasing preference of workers for this kind of employment. Figures presented to the Federal Court have indicated that 25 per cent of the Australian work force—over two million people—is casually employed.
As a remedy to what I think was an unfortunate situation generated by Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC, the bill before the House restores the prohibition on short-term casuals accessing federal unfair dismissal laws. It repeals the previous regulations so that their provisions can be written into the act itself. It retrospectively validates the regulations in question, and includes in the act a requirement that applicants for relief under the federal unfair dismissal laws lodge a $50 filing fee. This latter requirement will supplant a fee presently imposed by way of regulation. In short, the bill permanently restores the law governing the termination of employment of short-term casuals to that which was understood by the government, the parliament, employers and employees prior to November of last year.
The principle that short-term casual employees should not be able to access unfair dismissal laws was established under the Labor government in 1994. It has been strongly supported by this government. The principle was articulated in the coalition's election policy and was supported by the electorate. Some members opposite would like to claim that there is a bias in the workplace reforms initiated by the coalition government.
