Because they are still locked into some sort of 19th century Marxist interpretation of relationships as wholly class based, they cannot conceive of economic activity as being anything other than a zero sum game. As such, in their eyes policy apportions shares to the pie. They can say nothing of the size of the pie. Because some in our media are still stuck in the same Marxian time warp, there is a constant danger that this erroneous interpretation might be communicated to the public as fact. 
It is to the great relief of this government, and to the citizens of this country, that we have in the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations an articulate, thoughtful and comprehending advocate of 21st century reform. In the context of this debate, I am reminded of a speech given by the minister to the Industrial Relations Society of Queensland earlier this year—an excerpt of which appeared in the Financial Review—in which he articulated the industrial perspective of this government. He said:
This Government has tried to give employers a fair go, not because we see them through rose coloured glasses but because, in the end, that's usually what's best for most workers. We want to change the unfair dismissal law, not because we think workers should be liable to capricious sacking but because a few hard cases do not justify this handbrake on small businesses' ability to create new jobs. We want secret ballots before strikes, not because we want to disempower workers but because we oppose union officials using them as reluctant pawns in political campaigns.
The minister also said:
We're against compulsory union levies, not because unions should lack the standard capacity to charge a reasonable fee for a genuine service but because making workers pay for something they didn't request and don't necessarily need is a scam.
This is the key. This government understand that both workers and employees have a stake in commercial success. They share a mutual interest in the health of their business enterprises. This bill recognises that the decision by the Federal Court last year jeopardised the interests of employees and employers. We want to put matters right. As such, this bill ought to receive the support not only of this side but of all members of the House. I commend this bill to the House.

name: King, Peter, MP
text:
—I am delighted to be able to rise this evening to support the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002, which has been proposed by the minister. The amount of interest shown by the opposition in this matter is rather less than expected, which has caused me to rise to my feet rather earlier than I had otherwise anticipated. But it is a pleasure nonetheless.
—We could get the bill now. I've a couple I'd like to get through.
—If the minister is suggesting that the matter be now put, I am happy to support him. As he knows, I have tremendous respect for both his judgment and his leadership in relation to matters of legislation and everything that concerns ordinary Australians—
—And the bill?
—and particularly the bill before the House. Nothing is more important to the effective working of an economy than good industrial relations, because nothing is more important than keeping our workers in jobs and our businesses in business. The reason this bill ought to be supported is that it achieves that outcome. This is the first opportunity I have had to speak on the reform program which has been at the heart of the coalition reforms since it came to office in 1996. I was elected just some 12 months ago, but I have taken a particular interest in industrial relations law. I have followed with intense interest the progress of reformist legislation in this area since 1996 because I have a strong belief that reform of industrial relations law is absolutely necessary as a fundamental plank, as a precondition and as a starting point for successful government in the modern era. That has been a position expressed by others and perhaps most eloquently by the Prime Minister himself as late as today during question time. But it is true and it is worth repeating, and I repeat it because I strongly support it. As I have this opportunity to speak for the first time on the workplace relations legislation, I will take some time to review the principal act, the Workplace Relations Act, and illustrate how this bill will enhance the existing programs of the government in achieving good outcomes not just for industrial relations but for the economy generally. 
Firstly, let me focus on the Workplace Relations Act itself. It is, as the title suggests, an act concerning the workplace. That may seem a simplistic comment but it is an absolute truism about the direction of industrial relations since 1996 and since the introduction of the basic statute, the Workplace Relations Act, by the former minister the Hon. Peter Reith. Why is that so? The reason it was such a fundamental and important change is that industrial relations have been a critical issue for parliament in this country since Federation. It has been a matter that has been at the heart of the difference between the two principal parties, in government and in opposition, since 1901. The reason it is so important is that the focus in this statute is not upon an industry, not upon an association, not upon a trade, not upon an employer federation and not even upon a broader focus such as the impact on an economy but, rather, upon the workplace. That is the fundamental and paradigm shift in this legislation which I believe has been an important part of the reform program since 1996 and of which the government and the coalition can be very proud. Others also have outlined the actual outcomes in terms of good consequences for both the workers and the businesses of Australia.
The second aspect of the bill which is very important can also be taken from the title, and that is the fact that it concerns relations. It is a bill which concerns the relations between the employee and the employer. It does not concern a broader context. It is not a fight between capital and labour. The fight between those fundamental interests and those Marxist categorisations—the socialist concepts of the past—are now arguments of the past. 
—That is what you think.
—It is, therefore, very important that the focus of this statute since 1996 has been without demur from the opposition—until a short while ago when I heard from the member for Watson. The focus of modern industrial relations legislation should be upon relations, not upon worker interests or capital versus labour, as in the hoary old concepts of 19th century economists and outdated sociological theorists who no longer have any relevance to the answers for the modern world. The third aspect of this legislation which has proved very important is the fact that it covers an economy. It is comprehensive, and that is terribly important.
Debate interrupted.

name: McLeay, Leo, MP
text:
—Tonight I want to speak about multiculturalism in Australia, and I am pleased to see that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is here. Multiculturalism in this country has had a ripple effect throughout the world. It has struck me that there have been some extraordinary success stories both here in Australia and internationally and I would like to take the opportunity tonight to bring some of them to the attention of the House. To me, these are the jewels of Australia's multiculturalism. They show how successful we have been in nurturing our people, no matter where they have come from. These success stories do not sit easily with some of our current policies and attitudes, exemplified by the way we are treating many asylum seekers. 
We are largely a nation of migrants sourced from every corner of the world. While migrants from Europe—mainly from the British Isles—form the largest group, we have in the past welcomed people from lands and cultures that are very different from the European. Unfortunately, it seems this is no longer the case. We now live in a world of suspicion and fear; we treat many of our fellow human beings who want to come here in search of a haven as if they were criminals or worse. I think it is timely to look at some of the more interesting and successful results of our willingness to take in people from parts of the world that are very different from Australia.  
My colleague and friend the member for Grayndler last night mentioned Hazem El Masri, the Canterbury winger who is, of course, of Lebanese descent. What an amazing young man he is. Not only is he a brilliant footballer but he is a respected member of his community and a wonderful ambassador for people of the Muslim faith in Australia in particular. There are also people currently in other countries who were born in Australia, or who may have lived here for periods of time, who are now contributing in significant ways to their current home. Abdul Khaliq Fazal spent 30 years in Melbourne. Now he is a minister in the Afghan government. He regards himself as an Afghan and also as an Australian. He understands both cultures. The value of having such a person is almost immeasurable. There is Ung Huot in Cambodia, who served as co-Prime Minister with Hun Sen and was previously Foreign Minister of Cambodia. He was formerly an engineer with Telstra in Sydney. He has dual nationality: he is an Australian and a Cambodian. 
I have met people who have served in the Lebanese parliament who grew up in Australia and were Australian citizens. I have met MPs in Iran who spent many years in Australia as students. And, Mr Speaker, that is mentioning only people involved in our profession. There are many writers, academics, artists and talented people whose lives have been shaped by both their country of origin and their country of choice. If Australia had embraced a narrow, purely assimilationist policy, this two-way flow may not have ever occurred. I have chosen these examples deliberately because of the geographic locations. These people are not in Europe or of Europe but in countries that are, in varying ways, quite different from Australia. Some of them live in trouble spots. All of them have challenging jobs to fulfil. But all of them have experienced life in this country and all of them have their own experiences of life here which have helped them shape their attitudes. 
Multiculturalism enables us to recognise and appreciate the many different cultures in Australia, to embrace those differences and to respect and defend each other's right to be different. I am very proud of what true multiculturalism in Australia has achieved. I hope that we will continue to be a welcoming nation to those who need care and a safe place to live. Experience has shown that multiculturalism is not a one-way street. It is not just about people coming here; it is also about people leaving here and taking with them an appreciation of our way of life, which I hope makes them better able to face the challenges in their chosen careers elsewhere. We have been a great success. We should not forget it; we should rejoice in it. 
At Christmas we should remember those things that make us Australians, but more particularly we should remember that we must try to give shelter and help to those who need it. We should remember those people who came here and went out from this country again and have done great jobs in the world. The few people I have mentioned tonight are great examples of that, and we should not forget it. They have made us proud and we should be very proud of them.
